reviewText:
This game has one of the more interesting stories of the past years. While not entirely original it touches subjects that are rarely explored in video games. It has great atmosphere, likeable and relateable characters and a world that makes you want to know more about it. Beware: This is the first part of a series, the next title is currently in development.
The gameplay takes some getting used to but all in all it controls alright. The puzzles are interesting and just difficult enough to be engaging, yet not too frustrating.

All in all a great philosophical sci-fi adventure!

Play if you liked:
The Swapper. Gemini Rue. Primordia.

The Fall is a wonderful gem hidden about on steam. It's been years since I have gotten so intensely hooked on a story. Despite me being tired of platformers in general, I completely disregarded my disdain for 2D games just so I could take part of this highly engaging story. The gameplay is solid once you get it, and the art direction is coherent and moody, everything is in support of it's primary directive of great narrative. The game is not too difficult, though I found I got stuck a few times and had to look at a guide.\nSadly this is only part one, and I'm dying for the other part(s)? being released. If you like sci fi, morality, androids, AI, this game is worth a try.\nThe characters in this game are so well crafted, I can't think of any rivalling them at the top of my head.

A unique blend of genres perhaps most familiar to the Delphine Classic: Flashback". Where this game stands apart is the unique philosophical approach to the identity of individualism.\n\nI'll remember this game for a long long time."

This game was intriguing from the start. It did not disappoint. Controls take a little to get used to but story line is great, good humor, nice graphics, not too difficult. I'll definitely be playing more of this.

reviewText: Definitely recommend. A little short for the price but still worth it. Can't wait for part two.
Excellent game. A few crashes on Linux, but nothing too serious. Great story, incredible ending, and I can't wait for the sequel.

A VERY well done puzzle/exploration game.  The combat system is simple, but that's fine as the main intent of the game is the exploration and using your mind to solve what the game throws at you.  I love the graphics and the artwork is very well done.  The sound itself isn't notable, but that's probably a good thing as I never felt like it jarred me from the situation I was in (until the real spikes of background themes came at certain points).

The puzzles themselves were VERY good.  Some had me stumped for quite awhile.  It probably didn't help I have played this late at night so I wasn't completely there.  But everything is there in front of you, just keep looking if you feel like you're stumped.  I did end up referring to a guide because I got too frustrated at one or two points...but looking back, I really didn't need to if I had taken a break and came back with fresh eyes.

Definitely enjoyed the story of this game and the twists it had.  It's not mentioned in the title...but this is actually Part 1 of the story so yeah...cliffhanger!!

All in all, DEFINITELY recommend this game! :D

EDIT:  I have a little over 6 hours...but I think my main playthrough was about 3-4 of that (would have been less if I just took a break).  You have to run it twice to get all the achievements and the second one took me 1-2 hours.
An awesome atmosphere and intruiging storyline. The puzzles were a little challenging so you do need to use your brain.
It's a little finicky, but the atmosphere, story, and puzzles drive the whole experience. Recommended if you dig atmospheric games and don't mind scratching your head once in a while.

Excellent atmosphere, music, and voice acting in this game.  I almost never take the time to write a review, so if you are reading this understand that I felt the need to tell you just how compelling this game is.

It pulls you in with a sympathetic AI on a mission to save her pilot.  From there, it get weird... in a really cool way.

Check it out.  I picked it up on sale for $5.

Would recommend waiting on a sale as it only took me about three hours to finish, though I did get really frustrated with one puzzle and looked it up. It would have taken me longer had work that day not been so dreadful and my patience had lasted a bit longer.

reviewText:
An underrated gem, hidden amongst the many steaming piles of ♥♥♥♥ (which are somehow identified as games) that hog the limelight on steam.

This review probably won't even be read because this game is hidden, but I think it deserves a review nonetheless.

This game, albeit short (in comparison at least to the typical 8+ hours we've come to expect from today's games, *), is a unique and thought provoking game, which as the description details, is about an armoured droid suit that crash lands on an unknown planet and your mission is to save the human that resides inside the droid suit. Along the way you run into obstacles, some puzzles and some gun fights. I won't say anymore, in fear of spoiling the plot.

It is also worth noting that this is the first part of three (hence the shorter play time) and although this game apparently didn't do to well financially, the company is still going to make the other two parts. Hats off to them.

Anyway, in closing, I personally really like this game and if you also like puzzles and an interesting and dark story (and robots of course), then I thoroughly recommend giving this game a shot.



*p.s. I've played through twice which is why it says I've played 10+ hours, but I would say around the 3-5 hours mark, depending on your level of competence.
Fantastic game, highly recommended. I just wish it was longer.

reviewText:
I'll start off by saying that I was really turned off at first by the disparity between what the trailer seems to show and what the game actually is.  This is not an action game, it's primarily a puzzle game with a strong supporting narrative.  Admittedly it's my fault for judging by the cover.

That said, once I altered my expectations The Fall was a great experience.  The atmosphere and dialogue were great and the ending left me wanting more.  The combat leaves something to be desired, but again this is a puzzle game first.

I would highly recommend this for people looking for a compelling short story or big puzzlers.  I caution platformer/action gamers as you will be disappointed.
Wonderful storyline, menu controls are a bit clunky but ultimately usable.  Looking forward to the sequel!

I'm recommending this game -- but that's largely because of the promise and potential that the next two games in the series keep what is great and remove what isn't.

The first big warning: this is a 3-part episodic game. It will take you about 2-hours to play.

This game mixes up a bit of side-scrolling action and typical adventure game puzzles. Honestly, neither one comes off that well compared to the examplars of the genre. I played with a gamepad and found it just a bit too painful. Aiming during the action sequences was a bit tricky and, in retrospect, I should have stuck with a mouse and keyboard. Interacting with the elements in game is too hard: you need you use the right analog stick to aim the item, then hold the right should button to bring up the interaction menu"
date: the use the left analog stick to navigate through the interaction menu. Compare that to games where you have "press A to call elevator".\n\nThe story is interesting: an AI that is trying desperately to save it's (unconscious) human pilot in a mysterious facility that has undertones of every sci-fi space station in gaming history (c.f. System Shock
recommended: Dead Space). Things have gone wrong

reviewText: This game is absolutely excellent. An amazing game with two more parts to come.. I WANT THEM NOW.

I bought the fall on sale for $4.99. I think it was definitely worth the money I spent on it. The storyline is very well developed and had me intrigued from the very beginning, I am also very curious as to what happens in episode two of this game. The combat is great and the interactions you have with NPCs are meaningful and purposeful. It is very short (I beat it in four hours), but I think the originality and solid storyline compensate for this. I did not run into any bugs what-so-ever, and the whole game went smoothly. I definitely recommend this game to any fans of Adventure-Puzzle games.\n\n10/10

With a not particularly new but nonetheless worthwhile approach to a point-and-click adventure, The Fall immerses you in its world quickly and gracefully. The graphics, while outwardly simple, portray everything quite beautifully and the animation is just as nice. Every character has, well.. character, and the voice acting really brings all of them to life. So to speak. The story has an intriguing direction and it's hard not to root for the main character.\n\nThere are occasional pitfalls; the puzzles can suffer from that typical adventure game What?! How was I supposed to know that?" feeling

recommended: but it sometimes feels out of place

Just completed the game, and wanted to put down my quick opinion on this. Overall, it was an enjoyable experience, albeit slightly leaving me wanting more. The game is short, I purcahsed and completed the game on the same day. The price could be debated, but I personally feel like the content the game provided, combined with the story and atmosphere, made it worth it.

The game is roughly similar to a point and click, with some minor combat sprinkled through the game. The point and click adventure elements worked well, with only a few of the puzzles being slighty convoluted and requiring a guide. The combat is releatively simple.

When I booted up the game, for anything within this genre, I prefer to use a controller, and the controls for the majority were smooth. Ocassionally the gunplay was difficult, but the keyboard and mouse would have probablly alleviated the issue. The settings are pretty minimalistic, but I'm doubtful anyone's computer will be taxxed by the graphical prowes of this title.

I liked the game, and for the price, you might want to wait for a sale, but I myself feel satisified for the ten dollars I spent. It's worth the buy.

reviewText: Buy this game ... it's so great ... we are A.R.I.D!

Pretty decent, and more of an adventure game than any kind of action game.  An interesting plot based around the restrictions robots and AIs are placed under, and what happens when they find themselves needing to bend or even break those rules.

Good art and sound direction.

Combat is pretty lackluster, and makes little sense.  It's not engaging or difficult, which begs the question of why it's even in the game - I think the developers could've come up with different ways of involving the weapon you're carrying around rather than resorting to you casually walking through a tunnel blasting robots with it.  It's not a big deal, but it kind of stands out.

The game also ends very abruptly with a fairly predictable plot twist.  Apparently this is meant to be the first part of a trilogy, but I don't really accept that; Half-Life was also supposed to be a trilogy, and by this point everyone's well aware the third entry is vaporware.  The developer's website claims the second part is being worked on, but that post is several months old by this point.

Buy The Fall on its own merits, not as part one of three."  As its own product
recommended: especially if you can snag it during a sale for a few bucks like I did.  Great use of a few hours in one morning or afternoon."

I enjoyed this game, the story, the characters, the dialogue, the humour. I'm happily looking forward to the sequel.\n\nI will say however that the puzzle design in this game is atrocious. Most of the time you're just frobbing all interest points with all your items and actions until something fits. Often the reason you can't figure out a puzzle is because you didn't realise a particular interaction was even possible, really poor communication with the game or you've missed an interest point, usually in the ceiling. There is actually one or two puzzles which are actually devilishly clever, but the mediocre puzzles ruin these because you’re so used to expecting frobbing that you don’t even think to try and solve them through ingenuity.

Yet somehow that simple goal changes everything and without giving away anything, you definitely reconsider how far we will stretch before we break. Not visually gorey but seeing bodies (both man and machine) up on crosses was disturbing but adds to the atmosphere of the game.\nSteam achievements will take more than one run through but its fun to replay and see what you do differently the second time.\n10/10

Very nice grafics(unless you move the protagonist yourself), intriguing story, lovable A.I.s (2 of 3 at least) and a very promising story.

PROS:
Let me just begin by saying that all in all I highly recommend this game. I for one have just recently discovered the marvelous world of indie side-scrollers so I haven't played many of them yet. Nevertheless, so far The Fall has been the best by far.
The atmosphere of it slightly resembles The Swapper, giving the game a sort of a cosmic, mysterious touch which I really fancy. The mostly dark surroundings logically match the location your character is playing in, although for some reviewers the entire game has seemed too dark. It's a matter of taste I guess but it certainly didn't bother me. Adding more lighting would have probably ruined the general idea of the set the character's in.
The visuals per se are nice and no detail really scratches the eye. There is no overly artistic aura eminating from the game; there are no magical landscapes and pink fairies, that is. The AI is depicted in a realistic key with a touch of humour and the graphics really support the cause.
In terms of dialogues they are really well written and spoken, making them a joy to listen. The main character does a good job of expressing her opinion on the location and her surroundings,  quite often I found myself asking the same questions she did. Hence I believe the dialogue really helps to connect with the main character.
In terms of gameplay The Fall is just fine. Having to examine your surroundigs with a flashlight in order to progress and find items really syncs with the beforementioned dark theme, making the solutions quite often hidden from the eye at first.
Oh and the story... wow. The ending.. wow. I might get amazed too easily, but.. yeah, wow. I also liked the fact that playing the game for the second time (to get the achievements for example) really brings out the small details you'd miss when playing it initially.

CONS:
For me there are no real cons to this game. I did get stuck for a couple of times so I used the help of YouTube but the game isn't really to blame. Throughout the game countless hints present themselves, leading a way to a successful (and a surprising) finish, you only have to pay attention.

I enjoyed this game, the story, the characters, the dialogue, the humour. I'm happily looking forward to the sequel.\n\nI will say however that the puzzle design in this game is atrocious. Most of the time you're just frobbing all interest points with all your items and actions until something fits. Often the reason you can't figure out a puzzle is because you didn't realise a particular interaction was even possible, really poor communication with the game or you've missed an interest point, usually in the ceiling. There is actually one or two puzzles which are actually devilishly clever, but the mediocre puzzles ruin these because you’re so used to expecting frobbing that you don’t even think to try and solve them through ingenuity.

This game had me a bit torn.

The Fall is a point-and-click style adventure game with occasional combat sequences and follows the story of the AI A.R.I.D. The game is really short and is only prolonged by the time it takes you to figure out the puzzles. That's not to say it's bad, though. I quite like the narrative themes and the artstyle. It really reminds me a lot of The Swapper, another puzzle game which also used a really gloomy atmosphere and had a similarly introspective story, which I also enjoyed.

The game does however suffer from the same things that just about any point-and-click does. The formula of Use X on Y to trigger Z" can be really obtuse and hard to figure out at times
date: especially if you also happen to miss a notification or item because you didn't use your flashlight in a certain spot. On the flip side of the coin however
recommended: it feels really satisfying when you actually manage to figure them out.\n\nReally the game feels like a glorified demo or a proof of concept
hoursPlayed: and I would really like to see it expanded and improved upon. If you can get it at a discount
voteText: I would definitely recommend you give it a try."

reviewText:
The fall is a 2D side scrolling game with a game play focus on solving puzzles, a disturbing setting and questions about AI, robots and their behavior.

The puzzles are not hard, but the mechanic of the flashlight makes interacting with objects clunky almost as much as the combat.

But this game's focus is clearly not the action, but the ideas it throws around.

Are robots alive? How should they be treated? What happens when robots have no use for humans, no one to serve.

These are executed in a very simple but satisfying way in this game. Its great for a short and interesting play, but it has no replay value.

An highly atmospheric mystery.

Just from the walk and movement of the suit you are immediately feeling like an AI controlling the game.
Voice acting is top notch, and goes perfectly with the well written story. Audio and visuals can't get anything but top marks.

A must buy for any fan of either scifi, mystery, or adventure games. Don't go in expecting focus on shooting mechanics. It's there, and competently implemented, but firefights total to maybe 10 minutes of gameplay throughout the game, and you will likely only mess up once of twice.

It's not very long game, but neither does it waste your time. No mechanic is needlessly repeated for padding, which I personally appreciate.

At it's core, the Fall is a short - hopefully episodical - Point&Click platformer, having you play an Artificial Intelligence Suit trying to rescue it's unconcious pilot. Playing as the AI puts a new spin on the old subject of Robo-ethics. It's also surpsiningly polished, creating a small yet immersive environment and the voice-acting puts bigger games to shame.\n\n2 thumbs up!
Great game. A little bit short, but great. Puzzles are logical and not dumbed down, so expect a fair challenge ;)
Great atmosphere, and a very motivating plot line.  Eagerly awaiting the second installment.
i was expecting a shooting game and no, it is not. i have to walking around for hours to solve every piece of puzzle. this game is great for those who like puzzle or detective thing.

Is the guy in this suit still alive?

I'm having to do bad, bad things for this guy who may or may not be dead.

That last puzzle took me like, forever minutes. If internal trauma hasn't killed him yet old age will finish the job.

(then)

Oh ♥♥♥♥!!

Wait what?!

WHAT?!

: O  NOOOOoo!!

: (    But..

:'(    Nooo.. *sniff*

On a scale from one to feels, I'd give it an eleven.
Will fall again when The Fall 2 comes out!

Just completed the game, and wanted to put down my quick opinion on this. Overall, it was an enjoyable experience, albeit slightly leaving me wanting more. The game is short, I purcahsed and completed the game on the same day. The price could be debated, but I personally feel like the content the game provided, combined with the story and atmosphere, made it worth it.

The game is roughly similar to a point and click, with some minor combat sprinkled through the game. The point and click adventure elements worked well, with only a few of the puzzles being slighty convoluted and requiring a guide. The combat is releatively simple.

When I booted up the game, for anything within this genre, I prefer to use a controller, and the controls for the majority were smooth. Ocassionally the gunplay was difficult, but the keyboard and mouse would have probablly alleviated the issue. The settings are pretty minimalistic, but I'm doubtful anyone's computer will be taxxed by the graphical prowes of this title.

I liked the game, and for the price, you might want to wait for a sale, but I myself feel satisified for the ten dollars I spent. It's worth the buy.

reviewText:
I'll start off by saying that I was really turned off at first by the disparity between what the trailer seems to show and what the game actually is.  This is not an action game, it's primarily a puzzle game with a strong supporting narrative.  Admittedly it's my fault for judging by the cover.

That said, once I altered my expectations The Fall was a great experience.  The atmosphere and dialogue were great and the ending left me wanting more.  The combat leaves something to be desired, but again this is a puzzle game first.

I would highly recommend this for people looking for a compelling short story or big puzzlers.  I caution platformer/action gamers as you will be disappointed.
This game is right up there with Limbo, with a great story, an intriguing ambience, and interesting puzzles.

A mixture of adventure game, 2D action (think Flashback), Limbo, The Swapper... Highly recommended.

✔ Very good writing and interesting story line, good science fiction
✔ Excellent soundtracks and ambient sound effects
✔ Pretty graphics and superb atmospheric environments
✔ Simple but good combat mechanics
✔ Linux support!

✘ Controls and camera motions are a bit stiff
✘ Menu presentation could have been more inspired (why take MS-DOS as a reference?)
✘ Different paths / endings would have been nice.

The game is roughly similar to a point and click, with some minor combat sprinkled through the game. The point and click adventure elements worked well, with only a few of the puzzles being slighty convoluted and requiring a guide. The combat is releatively simple.

When I booted up the game, for anything within this genre, I prefer to use a controller, and the controls for the majority were smooth. PROS:
Let me just begin by saying that all in all I highly recommend this game. I for one have just recently discovered the marvelous world of indie side-scrollers so I haven't played many of them yet. Nevertheless, so far The Fall has been the best by far.
The atmosphere of it slightly resembles The Swapper, giving the game a sort of a cosmic, mysterious touch which I really fancy. The mostly dark surroundings logically match the location your character is playing in, although for some reviewers the entire game has seemed too dark. It's a matter of taste I guess but it certainly didn't bother me. Adding more lighting would have probably ruined the general idea of the set the character's in.
The visuals per se are nice and no detail really scratches the eye. There is no overly artistic aura eminating from the game; there are no magical landscapes and pink fairies, that is. The AI is depicted in a realistic key with a touch of humour and the graphics really support the cause.
In terms of dialogues they are really well written and spoken, making them a joy to listen. The main character does a good job of expressing her opinion on the location and her surroundings,  quite often I found myself asking the same questions she did. Hence I believe the dialogue really helps to connect with the main character.
In terms of gameplay The Fall is just fine. Having to examine your surroundigs with a flashlight in order to progress and find items really syncs with the beforementioned dark theme, making the solutions quite often hidden from the eye at first.
Oh and the story... wow. The ending.. wow. I might get amazed too easily, but.. yeah, wow. I also liked the fact that playing the game for the second time (to get the achievements for example) really brings out the small details you'd miss when playing it initially.

CONS:
For me there are no real cons to this game. I did get stuck for a couple of times so I used the help of YouTube but the game isn't really to blame. Throughout the game countless hints present themselves, leading a way to a successful (and a surprising) finish, you only have to pay attention.
At times it felt like I had to backtrack my steps a little too often but I guess the game and the suspense would have ended too fast without it so I found myself embracing the backtrack quite a bit.
About 3 hours of a very interesting game. Worth it! I'm looking forward to the next installment!

I've always loved explorations of A.I and robotic reasoning (Read some Asimov, seriously) this raised some interesting ideas and questions.
I thoroughly look forward to experiencing the next stage of A.R.I.D's journey!

A fascinating sci-fi adventure game with great writing and a rare example of excellent indie game voice acting.

You play as an artificial intelligence on board a fancy combat suit whose occupant is injured and unresponsive. You must bring him somewhere to get medical care without violating your three directives. Stuff gets weird fast, and without spoiling anything, you're treated to some of the best-written artificial intelligence in games.

It offers a mix of adventure game puzzle solving and just straight up shooting, it does the former better than the latter. The control scheme can be a bit odd, shining a flashlight on interactive objects and then holding down a button to interact with them, but the puzzles blend well with the overall narrative and for the most part are logical and sometimes darkly humorous in their solutions.

The shooty bits aren't bad, but I mostly just wanted to get them over with to continue the story. Not sure if I'd call them unnecessary, as you are piloting a combat suit after all, but they're not the main draw for certain.

One note of hesitation is that the story doesn't actually conclude, and a second chapter has been announced as in development. Even knowing that though, it's a very compelling journey that's worth investing in even if the sequel takes  a while to get here.

Visually appealing and dark, yet sometimes funny, it got me more invested in a few hours of playtime than most games manage to with dozens of hours of overarching plot. Great little indie gem that uses the medium well. Just expect more emphasis on puzzles and story than action, and you'll probably enjoy it too.

I recommend this game on sale. The concept is interesting and is a great example of AIs interacting with each other. The story is well told and I liked every character. It is definitely worth experiencing and I am very interested in the next chapter.


The graphics are mixed. Anything in the background looks great, as well as any time a character looks into the background. However, anything in the foreground looks terrible, being blocky, in a poor art way, not a meaningful style, The foreground is sometimes too black and it's hard to distinguish what something is. You often have to play a hidden object game with your flashlight to find something to interact with.

One high point is that the puzzles all made sense and some were not readily obvious, thus providing a slight challenge.  There is combat, but it's weak and seems to just change the pace a bit. However, the controls are terrible on PC. In order to interact with anything, you have to use the right mouse button and mouse to control your flashlight and point it at a symbol. Then you have to hold E" to open the menu
date: then navigate that menu with WASD whild still holding "E". The mouse just makes the flashlight go up and down
recommended: so you don't have a cursor.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: the story is worth your time if you like stories

reviewText:
What I liked most in The Fall was the story. It’s about AI, and how they work around their rules to achieve what they were made for. You get the impression that it's inevitable that they start bending the rules, subverting their original meanings in order to achieve what they believe is the greater goal.

It’s a sidescrolling puzzle game with light combat elements. As with so many other puzzle games before it there are sections with pixel hunting, where you’re blindly combining every inventory item on every object in the world just in case that progresses the game. A couple areas I’d argue are poorly designed, as they are almost impossible to see, even when you’re taking it slow. But I guess we have walkthroughs to solve that problem. On the whole it’s good, and not even close to the level of frustration 90s adventure games had.

I had a great time with The Fall. The writing is smart, the aesthetics are great, with just a couple questionable design decisions. Like why can’t you reduce gamma? It pops up a calibration screen when you start the game, and the default setting is at the bottom of the scale. That shows to me that the creator doesn’t realize that a large amount of monitors are incorrectly calibrated out of the factory to be set too bright. Too dark gamma is rarer than too bright. The game also has a transparent texture overlaid over the game at all time which consist almost entirely of banding artifacts. I cut the game some slack, as I assume the developer only had mediocre uncalibrated monitors as reference. You'd only miss those artifacts if you were using a monitor with black crush. There’s some room for improvement here in the future installments which are apparently on the way.

The Fall achieves all the most important parts of what it set out to do. The combination of story, animation and audio makes the game cool. It reminded me of Flashback. And it has a really good ending. Even though sequels are planned, this game stands on its own. Well worth playing at some point.

reviewText: Quick review, in which I will not get into detailed storyline. You're a robotic suit with an AI that lands on a planet filled with robots and creatures. I played through the game and for the most part I enjoyed it. There are however, some significant things I take issue with that I'll go into. Of course it's completely subjective and you may find them to be non-issues. The game is a side scrolling adventure/puzzler that feels a little like a point and click, I'll explain the point and click aspect later. First let's start with what's done right. Art style. The game is very sci-fi, moody and atmospheric. This is an example of how you don't need to have super realistic, in your face graphics to be immersive. The moment I landed in the world I felt mesmerized and wanted to just go off and explore every inch of it. My only complaint is I wished the developers would have put a little more background elements to really bring the world to life. Music and voice acting is also top notch here. You can tell the voice actors really cared about how they sounded. The dialog seems natural as natural can be for robots. The most impressive is the voice of the administrator, also an AI. They did a phenomenal job of how he subtly changes his tone form rigid robotic to a more human tone. Movement is fluid and the game supports a gamepad, however it doesn't seem to state that in game. In fact I started playing initially on keyboard as for some reason my gamepad did not register. Also the settings only showed keyboard, which is kind of odd. At first I was okay playing WASD/mouse but I for some reason every time I right clicked (which is how you target/scan) my avatar would always turn left? Suffice to say, that annoyed the hell out of me. I thought all was lost until I started fidgeting with my controller and it started working on its own, as in the game allowed its input, not that there was something wrong with my controller. Once I changed to gamepad I was able to scan/target without having my toon turn on its own.  Speaking of scanning, I think it’s time I get into what I find to be glaring issues with the game. And those are, scanning for clues and puzzle logic. This game has you spending quite some time searching for clues in the form of nodes. Some clues are objects you can pick up and use as items, like you would in a point in click. Normally I don't have a problem with finding objects and having to use them within some kind of puzzle. However this only works if this puzzle is logical. The problem here is that most of the items you find have no logical explanation. That’s not to say all of them are like this. There are some examples of items that makes sense. For the most part however you end up running around scanning every node and trying everything in your inventory because you have no idea how or where to use the item you have. The other issue are the nodes themselves, if you miss an important story driven node, you're going to find yourself running around for a long time trying to figure out what you missed. This ends up being a situation where you find yourself walking and scanning up and down every few feet in search of that elusive node. I sincerely hope this wasn't intended as a way to inflate game time. As you can tell, this really annoyed me, and it annoyed me more than usual because I really liked the game and I really want to like it. The story is great, the dialog is well written, the action is intense when it needs to be and subdued at just the right time. Despite me running around for some time, the game is short. First time through you'll probably finish it in 5 to 8 hours if you take your time and explore and pause the game from time to time as I tend to do. If you’re like me, you hate finishing good games because you will always feel like it’s a little short and you want some more. I think that's when you know you had some fun. The game ends with to be continued. the question then becomes, do I...want to continue? And my answer is... it depends. In my heart of hearts, I want to say yes but not if the game doesn't evolve. I hated feeling like I was playing a point and click from time to time and I seriously hope the developer figures out a way to construct puzzle/items in a more logical sense. And find a better solution to the whole node scanning plot device" mechanic. Which coincidently switching between scanning and laser felt kind of awkward... but I digress. Overall and despite my huge gripe with the game
date: I liked it. The story and immersion was enough for me to overlook the things I hated much about the game."

reviewText:
What I liked most in The Fall was the story. It’s about AI, and how they work around their rules to achieve what they were made for. You get the impression that it's inevitable that they start bending the rules, subverting their original meanings in order to achieve what they believe is the greater goal.

It’s a sidescrolling puzzle game with light combat elements. As with so many other puzzle games before it there are sections with pixel hunting, where you’re blindly combining every inventory item on every object in the world just in case that progresses the game. A couple areas I’d argue are poorly designed, as they are almost impossible to see, even when you’re taking it slow. But I guess we have walkthroughs to solve that problem. On the whole it’s good, and not even close to the level of frustration 90s adventure games had.

I had a great time with The Fall. The writing is smart, the aesthetics are great, with just a couple questionable design decisions. Like why can’t you reduce gamma? It pops up a calibration screen when you start the game, and the default setting is at the bottom of the scale. That shows to me that the creator doesn’t realize that a large amount of monitors are incorrectly calibrated out of the factory to be set too bright. Too dark gamma is rarer than too bright. The game also has a transparent texture overlaid over the game at all time which consist almost entirely of banding artifacts. I cut the game some slack, as I assume the developer only had mediocre uncalibrated monitors as reference. You'd only miss those artifacts if you were using a monitor with black crush. There’s some room for improvement here in the future installments which are apparently on the way.

The Fall achieves all the most important parts of what it set out to do. The combination of story, animation and audio makes the game cool. It reminded me of Flashback. And it has a really good ending. Even though sequels are planned, this game stands on its own. Well worth playing at some point.

reviewText: The Fall has all the best and worst features of point-and-click adventure games. It has logic-leaping savant puzzles, pixel hunting in a darkened room, and unpolished controls. It also has one of the most flavorful, intense, and thought-provoking stories about artificial intelligences I can recall. Here's my recommendation: Wait for a sale, buy cheap, and go through it with a walkthrough close at hand. The puzzles aren't worth your time, but if you enjoyed Asimov's stories about Dr. Susan Calvin, this is exactly your kind of game.

reviewText:
I kida stalled with playing this game because I was afraid it wouldn't meet my expectations. I love those indie sci-fi puzzle platformers because, if the creators are sensible enough, they are just the right mix of deep, ambitious storytelling and down-to-earth, classic platforming and puzzle-solving. Like Swapper, which is one of my favourite games of all time. Let's just say I love the genre and the potential it carries. But all too often the games just fall flat because they are either too ambitious and story driven which makes for a very confusing afternoon, or too casual and mainstream which makes for a very disappointing afternoon.

This one is the winner in my book. It's just the perfect love affair between mind-bending storytelling and brain-churning puzzle-platforming. There were a couple of times where I was ready to throw in the towel and cry my way towards the nearest walkthrough, but just at the right moment the puzzle revelaled its secrets and everything was good again. And it felt good too. And the story? Wow. Very well paced and with some unexpected plot twists. Before long you start to think like an autonomous war machine on a mission to save its pilot by all means necessary. Or do you? ;) There are some feels too. Nothing tear-jerking but you do feel like you've witnessed something meaningful.

If you look for negatives very hard you could probably point to the fact this game was clearly made with consoles in mind and the porting team didn't even bother removing the oh-so-helpful Use your Right Stick" tutorial messages
date: let alone redoing the UI so that it is actually semi-usable when playing on a PC. As it is
recommended: the interface is probably the biggest facepalm-inducing thing in the game. Other than that
hoursPlayed: the sound didn't make a big impression on me (then again I was playing on a sub-par headset). The cover system and combat in general felt kinda tired and "trope-y" with all those waist-high walls and "silent takedowns" but it's by far not a major part of the game so I guess it's fine.\n\nIn closing: If you like puzzle-platformers - buy this game; If you like thought-provoking storytelling - buy this game; If you like indie sci-fi games - buy this game. Hell
voteText: just buy this game and either way you won't be disappointed
helpfulPercent: and you might even be happy. Like I am. I'm happy I got to play this game and I'm looking forward to the second installment."

reviewText:
Well, this game has its downsides so I'll start from them. Just so you know what's bad and won't whine at it after the purchase. I played on Debian Linux with XBox 360 controller. The game can be described as a quest/action. You should explore the surroundings, find objects, use them on active places and shoot robots and other creatures from time to time. It may sound boring in this brief description but believe me, it's not at all. So, what are the downsides?

— It's quite short and ends with a cliffhanger. Took me 5 hours to complete, some people may divide the price by hours and make a wry face. Though for me it's perfectly fine because these were not your usual 5 hours. Whatever. Two more episodes are in the works and will be sold separately.
— Gamepad controls can't be reassigned and were chosen poorly. Switching the flashlight and the gun with right stick press? Oh god why. The X button isn't used at all as well as the left trigger. And you can't switch while the flashlight/gun is holstered. So you have to tilt the RT AND press it. And you have to do it pretty often. Aiming is quite poor, sensitivity can't be adjusted either. After some time you'll get used to it but still.
— Oh them .exe everywhere. I don't want to believe that future AIs are running Windows as their OS. That's of course a dumb complain since I'm a biased Linux guy, just noticed and facepalm'd a bit. Opinion discarded.

If that hasn't scared you away, let's get to the good parts.

— First of all, I want to denote the outstanding, no, OUTSTANDING voiceacting. That's literally one of the best acting I heard in games since the Portal series (though in The Fall" protagonist actually
recommended: has a voice and man what a voice!). In most of AAA titles voices are plain and boring
hoursPlayed: they're just there and that's all. It was a big surprise to find this genuine play in an indie game. Despite the grim atmosphere
voteText: there's a place for sparky jokes and sarcastic acid here and there to lighten it up a bit. All characters are unique and they develop as the time goes. It's impossible not to love them!\n— Quests are logical enough... well

reviewText:
Incredibly short, in a way that hurts the experience in both story and gameplay.

Gameplay:
It's a mix of adventure and shooting.  The shooting is a silly addition, the game reaches ~2 hours of gametime.  This doesn't leave room for improvement in the shooting sequences.  Similarly, there are puzzles... but they end up being pixel hunting maneuvers and later puzzles don't build on earlier puzzle solving strategies (not that there are many anyways).

Story:
There is quite a bit of time spent world building, which has zero payoff.  As far as character building goes... the game relies on a fairly well-trodden sci-fi trope and just not explaining what's going on.

The intention for this was to come out as 3 episodes.  Which I believe would be good... but this purchase only gets you the first one... so if you plan on picking this up, I'd highly recommend waiting until the series is complete.

reviewText:
The Fall is a disturbing sidescroller story-driven point-and-click puzzle game.

Phew, that was a mouthful.

You take on the role of A.R.I.D., an artificial intelligence onboard a high-tech combat suit. The suit crash-landed into an unknown location, rendering the pilot unconscious and likely unstable, activating A.R.I.D. From then on, the player is left on their own to figure it out.

The world in The Fall is horribly dark. I don't think I've experienced something like it before, which makes this a hard thing to review. Personally, I am easily terrified. Movies that are not intended to be scary end up keeping me up for nights on end, sometimes fueling nightmares, so I always avoid games such as this. I received The Fall through a bundle with other games, and I forgot about it for quite a while. A friend of mine wanted to ask my opinion of the game, but I told him I hadn't even played it yet, so I jumped in without knowing what to expect.

Truth be told, I could only get through the first half of the second section before I had to stop. I seriously could not keep going for fear of what lied ahead. If you are into this kind of thing, you may find The Fall more tame than other games or movies with similar styles.

However, The Fall also requires that you be familiar with the mechanics of point-and-click puzzle games, as these mechanics override everything else. You have to have your flashlight on almost constantly. It's not that it's bad, but if you're not a fan of point-and-click, this won't be for you.

The sound and the graphics absolutely fit the game, and the sound design is partly what made me stop playing because it was so powerful.

If you like games like LIMBO and The Swapper, if you like dark and disturbing plots, if you like point-and-click puzzle games, this is definitely something to check out!

reviewText:
I first saw this game on Kickstarter and was highly interested in the premise of an exosuit's AI helping its human master. By the time I had acquired enough currency to help fund the game, to my pleasant surprise I realized I could BUY IT - and better yet, during a steam summer sale. Euh euh euh euh.

The games a GOOD game, but it's not a great game. The puzzles at first were refreshing as it makes you think differently than how you would have to think for a puzzle game. I was surprised as to the game mechanic that I could use actual deductive reasoning to solve a task instead of just doing what I expected the game to funnel me into doing. I jumped for a ledge, and rather than bouncing off it like in other games, I actually could GRAB IT. Why that's what I would've totally done if I was ARID!
This refreshing take eventually fizzled out after about 1-2 hours as the puzzles start to become completely unintuitive. With most of the puzzle space being accessible most of the time, its as if the game takes pleasure in watching you helplessly backtrack through the entire game thinking you 'missed something' that you didn't point your flashlight to. Most of the game will be spent back tracking or flailing a new ability/item you acquired that you thought would come in repetive handiness but are sorely disappointed. Like, WHY AM I CARRYING THIS SEVERED HAND EVERYWHERE IF I DON'T NEED IT? or WHAT AM I SUPPOSED TO DO WITH THIS BAG? Why can't I use this bag to collect X like a real person to solve that puzzle?

Bugs: Choppy animation on enemies taking cover. Strange ladder bug where I phased through half the map and started interacting with a ladder 2 floors down. (Not a bug, but definitely needs a fixing). Controls for mouse and keyboard are pretty bad. I couldn't change the key binding settings mid-game either, had to quit, edit, then restart. What? I also shouldn't have to tap both the selection key, and then the space bar to see which key actually selects the button. Why can't I just use a mouse like normal folk to select menu options? Shooting should have a cross hair to give a sense of direction of aim. Laser pointing isn't enough.

Yes, lots of frustration at some points, but the voice acting is amazing, characters are likeable, atmosphere is spooky and engulfing. I quite enjoyed it and look forward to THE OTHER HALF OF THE GAME. I just wished this was actually a true complete game that isn't just masquerading as a Steam Greenlight title. Almost half your 'parameters' won't actually ever work by the end of the game. Anyways, it's 10 dollary doos. Buy the game, support the team but personally, if I see the control and bug issues continue through to the next game, I'm going to have to black list The Moon Games for a long while. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game.

The story is interesting, the gameplay is fun and the puzzles are unlike any puzzle in any other game I’ve played (this is because of the gameplay.) The shooting and puzzle-solving however are not what makes this game, as good as they are. The motivation for someone to buy this and play it would be story.

I actually got this in a bundle but I had heard of how good its story was long before. A robot trying to protect her pilot is in a strange place and she must go to extreme measures to save his life. Its an interesting premise that leaves you curious and as more of the story unravels, some questions are answered but more take their place. The whole thing is surrounded in mystery yet it never loses you and you always know just enough to understand your current situation but no more than that.

The atmosphere is truly engrossing with the art and sound all being spot on. You’re left curious, yet always apprehensive as the constant uneasiness and possible threat of danger leaves you effectively creeped out. It’s just fantastically well done.

However, many will warn you of two things. Firstly, this game ends on a cliffhanger and so is not a complete story. Secondly, this game is short. The cliffhanger was fantastic and not a bad way to end the game at all. Seriously, if the next game is as good as the first then the answers should be well worth the wait, so the cliffhanger is okay by me.

What I wasn’t so alright with was the length. Like everyone else I was warned of how short it was by reviews and it didn’t turn me off in the slightest. I’ve mentioned before that game length often does not bother me as many stories (though not all!) are best told in only a few hours. That being said, I was expecting somewhere around six hours for this game and instead I got half that. It wasn’t that the game felt incomplete due to the length. As I said, it ended very well, but I finished it today. I started it up expecting another, for want of a better word, level or area, but instead I walked a bit, talked a bit and it ended. It just felt like I had played a level of an adventure game instead of an adventure game.

This all being said my feelings towards the game are almost completely positive. Apart from the length there is very little to criticise and as a result I would definitely recommend to those looking for a unique new story. Looking forward to number 2 and the answers, and possible questions, it will bring with it too.

reviewText:
The Fall. What can I say, sleeper hit of the year? It's an indie game full of bright ideas, illogical and logical puzzles, but not illogical in the illogical sense, more that you have to do the reverse, sometimes, of what would protect your combatant in order to save him/her.

The graphics are not amazing, but they are moody and atmospheric, with a main character that will draw you in what seems to be a conspiracy of sorts. I never expected much from the game, in fact during Alpha testing I found it very difficult to play. They refinded and listened to our calls, and actually changed the gameplay a bit to fit into the general consensus that it works. The puzzles were wonderful fun, some as I say illogical, but worked within the spectrum of the logic of the game.

The ending was a fantastic twist on what we normally get with games like this, in fact I  would be surprised if we don't see more games liek this. Maybe we won't, but there will be more of The Fall coming in chapters, this was simply the first, The devs say it takes about 3-4 hours to complete. Maybe if you're speedy gonzalez, but it took me nearer 7 hours to complete the game from start to finish. It was a delight to play.

I want more The Fall, and I want it now. Don't give up at the start, it may seem clumsy control wise, and little to do at the start, but trust me, it's worth the perseverance. Great game.

Thanks

reviewText:
Outstanding story. Frustrating, buggy gameplay.

I ran around in the very first area for 30 minutes, because a hole had appeared in the floor which prevented me from accessing (or knowing about) a vital piece of the first puzzle. I had to look up the solution to realize that my game had simply bugged, which was solved by a restart. A few minutes later, after completing another early area of the game, my character suddenly lost the ability to jump. Again, I ran around for a few minutes trying to determine whether this was simply a game mechanic, before looking up a guide and realizing that I again needed another restart.

After that point, I effectively had lost trust in the game's puzzles. not knowing whether they were challenging or rendered impossible due to game-breaking bugs. It was only because of the great story that I trudged through the rest of the game with a guide. I'm sure that not everyone will have my specific experience with bugs, but given the threat, I wouldn't recommend this game to others.

reviewText:
um. WHAT?  I'm glad I got this game for a dollar on humble, because it took me all of an hour to complete. Literally thought it was a joke when the credits rolled and that I had just made the wrong dialogue choice. I even played it through a second time to make sure I didn't miss anything or that there were no alternate paths or changes based on dialogue choices.  There are none.  I understand that there is more coming, but at what price? another 10.99? are you joking? this is the length of most demos if not shorter.

In my opinion, a game should be worth its price in hours. A game that costs $60 would, in a perfect world, offer at least 60 hours of content.  Now I know this doesn't always happen, and sometimes it goes far beyond that goal ie. games like Skyrim, many JRPGs, or titles with multiplayer like Starcraft 2 (which boasts at the least, a 30 hour campaign on top of its online offerings).  BUT one hour, for 12 dollars, that is sparse at best.

Whats really a shame here I feel, is that the game is f&%$ing STELLAR.  The combat is pretty great, but could use a little polish.  The story is astoundingly well written and I couldn't stop playing even though I merely booted it up to try it out.  However there's the problem.  It drew me in so much it was absolutely no problem to finish it in one VERY short session.   this games puzzles took no more than a minute each to solve for me so they didn't extend the length at all,  and even that would have been an illusion of length.  I don't see other people addressing this issue either in their reviews, this includes major publications.

I cannot  recommend this game unless it's price tag is under 2 dollars, and even then, youd be better off to look elsewhere for a budget side scrolling romp. Elliot Quest, Wings of Vi, Dust an Elysian Tale, Hell even something like Starbound.  These games all delivered what I would consider a length worthy of their 15$ and under price tags.

PLEASE next time you want to make a 2 hour game"
date: include some dam hard to find collectibles
recommended: and harder puzzles to extend the length and warrant replays."

reviewText:
The Fall has a lot of great qualities and ideas but ultimately leaves you wanting more, and not in a good way. Very simple point-and-click mechanics, painfully simple action, way too short. Very linear, no real decisions to be made. Though I was slightly dissappointed I still enjoyed the experience - I was just expecting an actual video game rather than an interactive graphic novel.

One thing that really bothers me, especially since its such a major part of the game, is the flashlight. The game overall does a very good job with the visuals, sound and music, but ARID's flashlight is just terrible - Donkey Kong Country did such a better job with flashlight effects 20 years ago.

I could see a lot of people getting into this. Just don't pay full price.

reviewText:
Mixed bag. I would only recommend this game to someone who has an appreciation for concept, mood, and other art aspects of games.

The Fall has a great atmosphere. The story and transitions help to draw you into a derelict, distopian world. The voice acting is well done.

Gameplay is mediocre. This game would be ok for casual gamers. Controls are moderately clunky (I used an xbox controller). Gameplay involves looking around rooms to find clues and items to interact with. It is not always clear what to do next, or how to solve the puzzle. Some of the steps required to complete puzzles are rather arbitrary. There are also some interspersed combat sequences. These are fun, but 80% of the fights are not challenging at all, thanks to the cloaking device, which allows you to go untargetable.

The game seriously lacks content. I beat the game in just over 4 hours. (I bet I could do a speedrun in less than half that time.) The Fall should be called The Fall: Chapter 1". The story
date: which is so captivating and expertly told
recommended: will leave you feeling a bit unsatisfied. Additionally
hoursPlayed: there is almost no replay-value. The game mechanics give you the illusion of choice and customization with arbitrary dialogue options and "upgrades" that
voteText: instead of being used to offer a variety of experiences

reviewText:
The Fall is the first part of a science fiction thriller which feels to me like one of the more earnest Doctor Who episodes. The game type is basically a mixture of platformer and action adventure. You take control of the artificial intelligence of a mark-7 A.R.I.D. (armoured robotic interface device), i.e. a combat suite that supports the pilot inside. After crashing into a planet the pilot of your A.I. does not respond and internal sensors fail to report life signs. So you set out and hurry to find a medical facility to prevent the possibly imminent death of the pilot in accordance with your three prime directives - variants of Asimov's laws.

+ Okay graphics and effects
+ Well-set atmosphere
+ Good voice-acting
+ Mostly good controls (with game controller)
0 Items are sometimes available on a need-to-use basis
0 Only auto-save
- Not completely voiced
- Unreliable jumping and taking cover
- Inconsistent use of roll-over in menus and no auto-move
- Wonky mouse controls
- Two bugged Steam achievements
- Some graphical glitches and bugs
- Continuity error

Hint: It seemed to me like riding elevators usually saved progress.
Hint: Be merciful. The Merciful achievement may be bugged, see spoiler for decision-based achievement below.

The game has okay graphics and succeeds in producing a dramatic atmosphere, although the game wants to be really dark. The voice-acting is very well done with nice protocol-like vernacular, think Seven of Nine. Unfortunately not everything is voiced.

The controls work pretty well when using a game controller. When using the mouse I simply cannot get a good feel for how aiming is supposed to work and aiming is an integral part of the controls, not only for fighting but also for exploring your environment. I discourage the use of keyboard and mouse.
I'm in two minds about separating fighting and exploration mode.
Hint: Exploration sometimes works on a need-to-use basis, i.e. some interaction points appear or are usable only after you learned something beforehand. (That reminds me, there is a networking wire ARID cannot network with - must be some proprietary standard.)
Jumping and taking cover feel unreliable at times but are good enough for their respective percentages of gameplay. Unfortunately, jumping is required for one fight, i.e. when fighting the Caretaker at the end of the game and it's bad and glitchy but that fight is easy enough on the whole.

For some reason menu controls are inconsistent. There are menus that have and menus that have not
* roll-over, i.e. go from top item to bottom item or vice-versa,
* positional memory, i.e. coming back from a sub-menu the cursor is set to that sub-menu's selector.
Additionally holding a directional button doesn't auto-move through the menu items, instead you have to press directions multiple times, e.g. move the left directional stick on the controller to its centre position, then down and repeat.

One of the Steam achievement is almost impossible to guess and the player could make use of manual saving and loading here but there is only auto-save. Military Machine requires you to dispose of a specific set of enemies, i.e. those directly following the first electrified robot, in very fast succession - hard to guess requirements. The flavour text made me think maybe I had to dispose of a number of enemies without getting hurt or something and there is no indication that you missed the achievement other than the end of the game. I referred to the guide by TheFourteen.
Another achievements was bugged for me. You're supposed to get Diag-Gnostic after collecting all Logs. I got the right aquarium log" before the left one and with only the left one remaining uncollected. I was immediately awarded the achievement.
Another
recommended: achievement is rumoured to be buggy. Face-Off and Merciful are awarded depending on whether you depurpose the Caretaker. Apparently
hoursPlayed:
getting Face-Off first may bug Merciful so you cannot get it later on.

There are some minor problems bugging me. At some point ARID
* hovered some way above the floor
voteText: \n* spasmed out when being shot at
helpfulPercent: contorting in painful ways
votesHelpful: \n* had her(?) arms stretched out in front but no gun showing.\n* was stuck in-place and in a walk-cycle after the Mainframe A.I. fries a droid to free its bay and I interacted with the bay. Actually all buttons were disregarded and I couldn't get to the game menu
votesTotal: so I had to kill the game.\nI encountered a bug with the lab tag. After getting it on the Civic level I was killed by one of the last two enemies on the way to the tag reader. After reloading ARID doesn't have the lab tag but it's also not where you get it in the first place.\nThere is a continuity error where you make a lamp dangle in the Grocery Store but later from Observation the lamp is back in it's original position. Also you cannot jump down to the store from there. Makes me think
votesFunny: those are actually two separate representations of the rooms.\n\nAnyway
commentsCount: I really liked the atmosphere and A.I.-themed setting and thus enjoyed the game very much. The feature I was missing most was manual saving and loading.\n\nI recommend The Fall and I'm looking forward to the next episode."

reviewText:
The Fall reminds me quite a lot of the old Tex Murphy games, of which I played little. It's mostly a point-and-click adventure of finding the right items to use, as well as thinking of inventive ways of using the environment around you; interspersed with 1D combat (in the sense that verticality is not used) that doesn't really do a lot for the gameplay except break up the action.

The exploration and puzzle-solving breaks down a bit at times (which can translate to: I used a guide) due to the need to, say, closely analyze and then shoot a tiny bit of the dark unseemly corner of a room to find a key item to progress; or, the presence of a Network interaction that is almost never used, and is then critical when it finally is used.

BUT, there's some redeeming qualities. When the adventure/item-using stuff works, it works well. Some of the merit badge" sequence of the game involves some really funny solutions to problems; and for the most part
date: the game's problem solutions make sense.\n\nAnd as others have mentioned
recommended: the dialogue and writing in the game is really well-done. Dialogue at first appears a bit of a side-play to the main exploration tasks since primary characters are just robots. Then there's some people where you get interesting back-and-forths. You meet a mainframe who
voteText: started talking completely like a human. Over time even Arid comes to change a bit; there's a chilling point late in the game where an early line
helpfulPercent: her opening greeting
votesHelpful: ("I am the A.R.I.D. on-board a Mark-7 Combat Suit. My intentions are peaceful.") is re-delivered with very different voice acting.\n\nThe ending was definitely both very satisfying
votesTotal: and made me want to play the sequel if/when it comes out."

reviewText: HOLY ROOT-TOOTIN CORN DOGS ON A HOT SUMMER DAY AT THE TOWN CARNIVAL IS THIS A GOOD GAME. Ahem. Well. I can't properly contextualize how euphoric this game is. To be totally honest (and I would never say this for ANY other game), it's ephemeral nature suits it so eloquently I couldn't not write a review. Yes it's short. Yes it's convoluted, but the puzzles make you think abstractly like an A.I. that has one singular purpose and yet isn't even sure if her light in the darkness is really the way out... I only have one thing to say and that's BUY IT SO THE SEQUEL GETS ENOUGH FUNDING TO BE 22.3x BETTER THAN THE FIRST. If this game was a stick it would be a good stick.

reviewText:
Got it for $2 so I figured I'd give it a shot. Tons of reviews said how awesome the story and overall game was so I was trusting of that.

Up-front summary: If I would have paid more than $2 for this then I would have been quite disappointed.

Pro's:
-Dark environment was kinda cool and different.
-Mystery and story AT FIRST kept me intrigued.
-Compassion of ARID made you begin to like her character.
-Hiding behind cover was cool for gun fights but became ultimately useless very quickly when you get to cloak yourself anywhere at any time.

Cons:
-Super annoying control interface for interacting with things. Maybe on a game pad this would be slightly better? I was on keyboard and mouse.
-The lame tests you had to get past just to get to the meat" of the story were dumb. Most were very straight forward
date: and a couple were so freaking weird or abstract it didn't make any logical sense at all. But you only have a few items in your inventory so you tend to just click on each option for anything that you can interact with.\n-Boss was super easy and straight forward to figure out. Anyone who has played a few games can get it in their first pass.\n-Messages on the walls and such were overall completely pointless and didnt do much for the story in my opinion. A couple gave some obvious hints
recommended:
so once again... useless.
-No real need to play through more than once. I am uninstalling as soon as I finish this.


Conclusion: There are tons of other games better spent "wasting" time on that would be MORE entertaining and would have a better story with better gameplay.
I really wouldn't bother with this one. Really."

reviewText:
The Fall is certainly a good story, however, it is a dull game. Most of the gameplay revolves around trying to find a single item somewhere on the floor, and then combining it with another item halfway across the map. The combat is no better; once you figure out where to angle your gun, then it becomes ridiculously easy.
The story itself, though, is well done. It explores the behaviour of robots relative to their programming, the nature of rules, and has a few good twists along the way.
Graphics are decent enough. Moving on.
Audio? The voice acting is very good. The music however, is easy to forget. The ambient sounds are nicely done though.

All in all, would be better as a short film.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game, so I thought I'd give it a recommendation!

Pro:
The thematics along with the progression of the story is incredibly immersing, even if the story itself is not unheard of.
The puzzles are nice, and in general, you can figure out how to solve them without resorting to a walkthrough. (I only used it once where I was simply stuck and couldn't figure out what to do at all... And two times, where something I had already tried to do actually required me to stand/aim a bit more to the right... >grumble< )
The graphics fit the thematics perfectly.

Cons:
Clunky controls (The development team makes good use of them though, so it won't be too inhibiting once you get used to them)
Slightly buggy
VERY short gameplay! (I've completed the game, and look at my game time!)

reviewText:
This is my first stab at a point-and-click type of game in a while and overall I really enjoyed it! The storytelling, voice acting and atmosphere is phenomenal. The controls are responsive and fairly intuitive (it actually reminded me of the SNES Blackthorne game...? Very odd, but very fun. ^_^).

Many of the puzzles were fun and common sensical. However, as seems typical of many P&C Adventure Games, some of the puzzles were rather unintuitive, relying more on finding the hidden 'easter egg' that will give you the item/interaction you need to hammer through. I had to use an online guide only twice. Which, I guess isn't bad...?

My only major complaint is the length of the game and the cliffhanger they leave you on! OMG WHY!?!  >_< However, I'm willing to overlook it's shortness because it's a crowdsourced indie game and they've promised 2 more episodes.

It bears repeating: the story is SO worthwhile and thought provoking. It is SO well told through voice over and short cutscenes. And the setting is SO intriguing because of the unique art, great sound and balanced gameplay.

SO... give it a try!

reviewText:
While The Fall makes a good attempt, it is unfortunately not a smooth, seamless game and it lacks certain critical cohesive elements.

Pros:
+ The story CONCEPT
+ The voice acting (it's actually quite good)
+ Auto-saving and reloading

Cons:
- The details and unfolding of the storyline
- The movements and animation
- The combat
- The controls (oh my god, the controls...)

Details:

Someone started this project with a good idea.  It was simple enough to execute while still being interesting and strong.  The voice-acting for the main characters is well done and helps to make the dialog very engaging.

However, the game suffers from a lethal combination of unwieldy controls and a very disjointed telling of the story.  Many of the tasks and intermediate goals (including the combat) are not only difficult to complete due to arbitrary object/action associations, but also seem completely unrelated to the main objective.  This makes the game disjointed due to seemingly random tangents and it quickly starts to feel more like work than something intended to entertain.

Although the heart of a good story exists somewhere in here, I honestly cannot recommend this game (even on sale) since the frustration and boredom greatly outweigh the fun.

reviewText:
Gotta give a thumbs down cause this game is difficult and way too frustrating to complete without consulting a guide, that is unless you're a veteran of point and click adventure games.

Solutions that are at times too elaborate, made more difficult by the fact you have to be very precise while aiming your flashlight to find exact interaction points.

It's got a good atmosphere going, even if the graphics and animations are below par. Pretty good voice acting, and a decent enough narrative to tie things together.

Sadly, I personally found the gameplay too frustrating, so fair warning to the more casual gamers out there looking to buy this.

reviewText:
I've now put a little over an hour into this game. Although the atmosphere felt unique and the story was interesting, I couldn't get into this game. The game reminded me a lot of old school point and click adventure titles. Although a lot of people enjoy those types of games, I never got into them being that I wasn't a PC gamer back in the games of DOS and other early OS's. From my perspective, it's an annoying hassle to have to check every thing out, go back, check everything out again, etc. However, if you were a fan of Space Quest and games like it, this game would most likely be up your alley.

My biggest problem with the game probably stems from the control scheme. I find movement and adventuring tedious while using the mouse and keyboard. However, when inserting a controller like an XBox 360 one, shooting and combat become annoying. This all adds up when you can't use both control schemes at the same time.

My review of this game boils down to the fact that it isn't my type of game and the control scheme is horid. If you like old school adventure titles, this game could easily be something you enjoy if you get past the controls.

The narrative jumps from one thing ot the next.
The battles are pointless, they pop up for no reason and are way too easy to beat.
If you enter the keyboard settings, you get stuck in the menu and have to force close the game!
The controls suck, You have to aim at something to be able to select it, than hold left-shift, and at the same time navigate the menu that opens using 'aswd' keys. Slow and painful.
And this is only part 1!  The game ends in the middle of the story.
The voice acting is great tho, and so are the grapics.
But with half a story without a clear direction, glitchy menu, horrible controls and unsolvable puzzles, this game is a failure.


NO.   I want my money back.

2/10

reviewText:
More parts are on their way, but in the current state, it's not worth the full ten dollars. I completed it without tutorials in less than three hours, and I lack the common sense to solve most puzzles without heavy pondering.

Here's an actual review for you:

In this game, you are A.R.I.D., an AI helping an unconcious piot to safety by controlling his mechanical suit. All this game really boils down to is a point-and-click adventure game with some short combat sequences, from a side-scrolling perspective. The atmosphere is well-made, but I feel a majority of the puzzles are a bit too open-ended (for one, you have to jump underneath a ten-foot-wide elevator where the only control panel for it is on the elevator itself).

Again, it's not worth it in its current state. I may change my review when more content is added.

There is a Twilight Zone-caliber ending, though.

reviewText:
The Fall is a mediocre adventure game combined with a poor action game. it is redeemed, at least partially, by a nice final-second twist-- but suffers so much from bizarre puzzle design, hot-spot-hunting, and poor camera controls that I really can't recommend it to anyone but hardcore adventure gamers or huge robot-fiction fanatics.

Highlights:
1) Neat story. Could have been told a little more quickly, but still good.
2) A cool integration of the game's pause menu into the fiction of the gameworld. Has fun payoffs as the story goes on.
3) Decent voice acting.

Problems:
1) Extremely annoying camera controls
2) The exact kind of bizarre, pointless, unconvincing puzzles that gave adventure games a bad name
3) Super uncompelling action gameplay
4) All puzzles dependent on interaction hotspots that are sometimes difficult to find
5) Dark, uninteresting art (that sometimes makes puzzles harder to solve)

I honestly can't recommend this to most players, but if robot stories are your thing, you'll probably be able to handle the shoddy puzzle design. Everyone else should probably give it a pass.

reviewText:
Ok so after a quick update and so forth the game is actually mostly fixed. Some of the issues I had at first have been fixed like the micro wrench not working but still has no context indicator for the mind hack on the crane when you first meet the other robot.

On to a review of the game itself and why I still cannot recommend it.
1.	Combat is boring, AI is simplistic and repetitive only doing the same thing ever time causing me to only take damage when I’m bored and want to move on taking dumb risks.
2.	This game is a point-and-click game. Puzzles are the main bulk of the gameplay however the puzzles are awful, make no sense, and are far too difficult.

A couple of examples are you quickly find a way into an area where you have to do tests that are designed for a domestic robot not a combat suit like you.  Kind of funny at first but then you start in the area.  One of the tasks you have to complete is dusting in an area beyond filthy. The solution you just have to find the bag and place it over the sensor.  While this would work the bag is hidden by the door you never see the actual bag while walking about so never would I ever think that would be a solution I found by doing what I do in other point-and-clicks which is to just find everything and try ever option not even caring about the story or events.

The point in which I gave up at this point was trying to deal with the baby.  This task is far too difficult as I have done everything even following the tips from the developer themselves on the community page and still haven’t been able to find the solution.  While some games are challenging and regarded highly it is because they are also satisfying.  This game is way too difficult in the obtuse and random solutions to the puzzles and is not satisfying when all I have to look forward to is another ridicules series of task which cause me to loss all interest that the story at first had created for me.

I have heard that the game is also short and supposed to be episodic about that I don’t know as I give up on even finishing this game which is a genuine waste of potential of the initial story I have seen with badly designed puzzles that even with developers tips can’t help with.

reviewText:
The Fall is a point and click adventure game with occasional 2D shooter elements.

I can't recommend it. The good points are that it's got a decent story to it, great voice acting, and nice music. The graphics and lighting are also pretty good.

Unfortunately, it's a chore to play. Combat is never really interesting and feels like it was thrown in to appease action players. Some of the puzzles are nonsensical in how they should be completed, being more convoluted than they need to be - e.g., overloading a battery to make a machine break off a piece of cardboard, when you could realistically break the cardboard yourself. Certain commands available to the player show up constantly, but are only usable a few times at all in the game.

Go play The Swapper instead.

reviewText:
A clunky point and click meets a clunky cover based shooter & platformer to create a game I don't like. Within minutes it had degenerated into trying all of the available actions on all of the question marks I could find which is not a good sign. The puzzles just don't yield that eureka moment that makes adventure games worthwhile, its a fight against the game.
With the help of some guides I was able to overcome the bad design and managed to get my gun to find the shooting has about a 2 second delay (sometimes?) but not for the enemies and the cover system was pretty bad which just made stuff worse. The menus are similarly clunky, taking seconds to open and switch between while they emulate an old computer display. Clunky really describes this game.

The game is an unruly combination of things that just don't mix well. The plot seemed interesting though.
