I won't go into too much detail about The Fall's storyline, as you can check the store page for that if you haven't already.  Instead, I'll talk about the rest of it so far as January 2015.

This game is thankfully uncomplicated in its control scheme and gameplay mechanics, and the atmosphere of it is seriously tense and dramatic - perfect for dystopia effectionadoes.  The game is quite reliant on problem solving, and many of the methods for dealing with situations have results that seem a little unorthodox - which, while fitting the theme and story very well, can leave one rather frustrated.

However, for those of us who don't want to miss out on the rest of the story because of one little puzzle, there's thankfully a number of walkthroughs out there that can help you.  Alternatively, since there isn't much that directly hinges on doing things in a set order (that I know of anyway), the tactic of brute-force use-everything-with-everything and do-everything-again-just-to-see-what-happens thing can work.

The combat system is fairly decent too, and while currently lacking in variety, due to the relatively low health and shields of your character it can be rather intense.  Also, quite fortunately, there are frequent saving points before combat situations so that if you die, you won't be too far behind.

All in all, I like this game and I recommend it to anybody who's got a bit of time up their sleeves and an itching for a gritty and dark puzzle game.
It is an adventure game with janky controls and puzzles wrapped around a great story with good voice acting.

I bought this game after listening to Giant Bomb's Game of the Year podcasts, where they named it Best Story and soundly spoiled a twist or two, so I went in with expectations. And, to be honest, neither the storytelling nor the story lived up to their high praise.

It starts off really, really good. The first 30 minutes *is* outstanding: mysterious, menacing, brilliantly told and stunningly visualized. If there's one thing this game nails it's robots talking to other robots, and it offers perhaps the best representation of robot 'culture' (if there is such a thing) in sci-fi that I've seen. The world is weird, the characters are weirder, and the atmosphere is thick throughout.

But then you run into the puzzles. I'm not an adventure gaming veteran or anything like that - I've played a few in my time - but the puzzles in The Fall are *so* obscure, *so* out-of-left-field and backtrack-y that it immediatly halts any momentum or goodwill the game conjures up in the first 30 minutes, deciding instead to take a hour long detour into pure puzzle-solving that feels like fluff to a game that's already achingly short (my steam time is 2 hours). Here, the story not so much evolves as mutates, getting sidetracked from the initial danger and wonder of that first half-hour. It continues to explore some interesting philosophical approaches to robots (though not particularly unheard of ones), but starts loosing its footing quickly.

The ending is a little stronger, buoyed by more directive and a brutal ending, but too many of the motivations behind characters are left unclear and combat - while unobtrusive but never exceptional in the earlier parts of the game - starts to become an annoying crutch. Since you are so fragile and your combat options are so limited, throwing more enemies than you can handle coupled with bad controls was incredibly frustrating in the final 20-stretch. By the time the game reached its climactic confrontation, I just wanted it to be done.

Luckily, about five minutes later it was. Both a blessing and a curse, The Fall's 2 hour run-time gives it a pleasant short-stort feel while still leaving questions open for the next two chapters. However, it's too short to give one character in particular much interesting motivation, which isn't great because there are only three in the entire game. The story itself is...unexceptional, though, for the most part, well told. The main character, A.R.I.D., and a friendly (or is it?) computer AI she meets along the way are both well voiced and written, and the world they inhabit is always fun to explore, if not being the most fleshed-out. Some character beats, however, fall totally flat - mainly one weird 'morality' choice near the end comes out of nowhere and means next-to-nothing.

Did listening to the Game of the Year stuff bias me against this game? Maybe. Probably. But in a year where we had good, emotional storytelling it The Wolf Among Us and This War of Mine, The Fall barely holds a candle to the rest. It didn't hit me as particularly better than other indie-sci-fi games (if you want a great one, go buy The Swapper). Overall, it just didn't feel that special. It never could live up to those first 30 minutes.

This is unfortunately a game with lots of wasted potential. The biggest reason for this is the controls, it simply doesn't work and makes you frustrated throughout the entire game (this applies to both keyboard/mouse and controller). Another reason is that the puzzles are being more or less spelled out to you whenever you find clues.

Will I play the second game in the triology when it releases? Most likely not. Should reviews point out significant changes to the above, then maybe, just maybe.

I really wish I could recommend this game, but I can't.

The Fall is a solid platforming puzzler, with obvious influences from the numerous similar releases in this genre whilst lathering on its own brand of a dystopian cyberpunk. It’s interesting to be required to explore rather than being rewarded for it, a trope few games have invoked in the past. My experience was marred by my logic being out of sync with the developers however, something which is hard to blame the game for but doesn’t change the fact that I felt the good parts of the game were hidden behind too much cruft. The Fall still provides a solid experience however, one I’m interested to see how it develops over its subsequent releases.\n\nRead my full review here: http://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2015/01/09/the-fall-i-must-protect-my-pilot/

I picked this up due to a recommendation in a review of another sci-fi game. It's nothing special, unfortunately. The controls are really awkward, and you have to backtrack a lot, even if you are following a walkthrough. It is pretty frustrating that a lot of the interactive items are not visible unless you shine your light directly on them, which means you spend a lot of time scanning rooms randomly. And then as soon as a scripted event happens, your light disappears, so you need to re-arm again to react. I guess a sequel might be worthwhile if the controls and interaction were improved because the story was okay, but I wouldn't recommend this one unless you are really starved for some sci-fi.

Very good game. I would describe it as something between Flashback (action sequences), Swapper (environment and atmosphere) and Point-n-click gameplay. The graphics are dark and nice, although the brighter light in the center could be avoided, the sound is good and the gameplay is nice and simple. The general atmosphere of the game is one of abandonment and desperation (the fact that the later comes from a A.I. makes it even stronger).\nThe plot becomes more interesting as you proceed in the game and the best part is the ending. What's also interesting is that everything is shown from the A.I.'s point of view.\nWhat I found a bit annoying was that I had to move the flashlight of the suit" up and down very often in order to find the interaction points... Other than that

reviewText:
This 2d side scroller is essentially a point and click adventure game with some shooting elements that break it up a bit that sometimes feel slightly too hard. Yet the checkpoints are ususally fair enough that it is not much of a problem.

As an adventure/puzzle game, its puzzles range the gambit of plot advancing clever to requiring me to pull out the gamefaqs. None the less, this game is an enjoyable short experience and one that I would recommend.

The story, dialog, and the bleak world ARID finds herself (itself?) in are the real draws here. A notable plot/game mechanic is that many of ARID's abilities are locked behind logic gates that require you to subvert her own directives in order to fulfill her ultimate goal (Prime Directive) of saving her unconscious and in critical condition's pilot life. This leads to a rather ominous progression that was enjoyable to watch as she moves about a bleak and ruined world that I want to learn more about.

This is a short game, only about 3 hours long as its only the first episode, however I very much look forward to seeing how this story will end.

10/10 will play again.

The Fall as everyone else has said by now is one of the best experiences (at least in my opinion) to come out of a video game in awhile. ONE OF. It's not the top one but is probably top ten IF not top 5. Anyway

The game isn't atrociously impossible yet still challenging at least where the puzzles are concerned. The combat isn't all that difficult, take cover, shoot, stealth destroy droids and take their energy for yourself, camo when necessary, etc etc. The puzzles are creative. (Especially the baby one) And the game is about 3 hours long depending on how quickly you complete puzzles. The dark story coupled with the foreboding atmosphere are the best qualities of the game and really sell the game. Oh did I mention that A.I are awesome and scary at the same time.

Not much else I can say about the game without getting into spoilers so go try it out its fun, requires you to think and starts out poking you like a younger sibling trying to get arise out of you to full on curb stomping you by the end.

Enjoy
LOVED THIS GAME!

The Fall is advertised on Kicksterter as a three part trilogy. This is part one of the trilogy. I don't know if parts two and three will come as updates, DLC, or new games entirely.

The Linux port is fantastic. I haven't tried a PS3 controller, but it works fine with a 360 controller. Mouse and Keyboard controls are decent as well.

I'm very VERY picky when it comes to 2D platformers, and I really enjoyed this game. The amount of detail that went into the environment, the asthetic of the game, the story, it was all amazing. It was rather short, but it's only $10. Well worth it in my opinion.

My only complaint is that the game seems to intercept global keybinds, so taking screenshots is difficult, and you can't tab out unless you're in a menu.

reviewText: Unique gameplay with a rather fun story. Interaction menu takes a little getting used to, but once you do it feels pretty natural. Definitely enjoyed it, although there isn't that much replay value. Wish Episode 2 was out already!

For those who know me know that I am a stickler for a good story and in my mind that is all that really matters in a game. With a exception to smaller side elements such as game weight on disk, graphics, gameplay style, and sound. Now normally I do not like horror games as they spend to much time playing up the horror and gore element of things like jumpscares and vicera. I feel this game was truly an exception for the following reasons.

1. It was a 2D sidescroller with horror elements and very well done sound effects  to keep me on the edge of my seat. In this game the developers were able to get the key aspect of horror that most developers dont and that is subtlety. While there was a constant theme of death and dispair (which comes with about 90% of game titles these days anyway) the key timing of certan audio ques was astounding.

2. The game was small on disk but that did not compromise the depth of story telling that was done here. This was reenforced with a small realistic set of charecters for the genre. Which I feel is not something that most games anymore can pull off well especially triple A titles.

3. The voice acting was very good for the charecters protrayed and the choise of dialouge was strong enough to provide the growth that was needed over the length of the story in these charecters.

All in all 10/10 I would most definitely play this game again and I look forward to purchasing and seeing what direction the developers will take this story in when part 2 when it is released.
Really good game, I hope they make a sequel. Short game but I got for five bux so excellent price point.

i fell for this game its a good game graphics are good gameplay is hard but not to hard its a game that makes you feel amazing after you solve the puzzle the combat is a little weird but still very enjoyable the dialogue is a little clunky but overall 9 out of 10 if there is another game would play

I can't recommend it enough. It's super tight, looks great, has a really great story that's done really well, and knocks many a triple-A game on it's ♥♥♥.

It's smart and fun and slick as hell.

Story and atmosphere so outstanding i would call it one of a kind.
Great story, challenging puzzles, lightly sprinkled with a few awesome combat sequences. Thought provoking and just all around fun, can't wait for episode two!

It's a tough decision for me on whether or not I should recommend this game, it has some really outstanding qualities, but overall I don't think I can fully endorse this game to anyone.

I will start with the positive qualities.
~The voice acting is outstanding, much more than you'd expect from a greenlight/indie game.

~The narrative is really quite enthralling, as you discover how far an AI will push its operating parameters to accomplish its main function. The story leaves a bit to be desired at the end, but was overall very interesting, and I was not bored by it.

~The atmosphere is fantastic. If you take the time to appreciate it, it's chilling and compliments the narrative very well. Hands down, one of the best atmospheres I have experienced since Dead Space, or Metro.

And now for the cons.
~The price. I bought this for $4.99 while it was on sale, and couldn't imagine paying $9.99 for a game this short.

~The length. Steam says I have just over four hours in this game, which included me sitting at the pause menu while I waited for my pizza to cook. (This goes hand-in-hand with the price.)

~Replay value. I don't think I will play this again. There is no branching narrative, there is no alternate ending, there is nothing else to do after you beat the game once unless you care about Steam achievements (I don't.)

~Controls. I played this with a controller because it seemed the logical way to go from reading the other reviews, and even still the aiming was awful, and the interactions with things was tedious. You have to take out your flashlight every time you wish to interact with something, even if it's right in front of you. Perhaps it was just my thumbsticks, or the sensitivity, but I was personally not a fan of the controls.

~Combat. Maybe it was just me, but the combat was really stale. You can basically stand there and cloak until they stop shooting, hit them three times, and then rinse and repeat. The poor aiming controls do not help this.

TL;DR:
The Fall is a story and atmospherically rich game that unfortunately didn't focus on the controls and gameplay elements enough to justify spending $10. (I picked it up for $5 and I'm still a bit disappointed.)

6/10 (I really do want to give this a higher score)

FINAL THOUGHTS:
I really want to recommend this game because of the story but, to me, it doesn't outweigh everything else.
***
I'm also hearing talk of this being the first episode of this series, and if that is the case (and the games are similar), I think it's a grab at money and they could've waited on this release and made it longer.
Great!

This episode tells an interesting story, but can be frustraiting at times when you can't figure out how to get past a certain puzzle. It offers an update to the point and click mechanic with makes it's easier to find objects to interact with while not taking away the fun of figuring out how to interact with it properly. Combat is okay, I found it charming, but it is very simple and not enough for someone looking for an action game. I look forward to the next episode, and recommend for those who  don't mind getting frustrated with not knowing what to do next and like robot based stories.

Well worth playing through. The story is unique and well done. The voice acting is convincing and kept me pulled into the story. Gameplay was great and kept me interested in what can sometimes be a boring genre (adventure). In short if you like scifi story play this game!
Incredibly intriguing.

Though it feels like a game that take only 4 hours of gameply to complete should get some backlash, The Fall manages to sidestep that completely and make me want more from another installment. The puzzles are well-designed which can befuddle you for a time without being excuciatingly difficult and the gameplay is imaginative.\n\nWhile the plot itself is slightly predictable, I would heartily recommend this game should there be more coming from Over the Moon. This game has clearly been designed with sequels in mind and The Fall is a brilliant start to this franchise.
Gripping and challenging, The Fall is an awesome Sci-fi puzzle/horrorish game (with no jump scares!) that I HIGHLY reccomend if you like AIs or AI theory.

I'll be completely upfront about this, you should definitely consider getting this game. The Fall is part one of a trilogy, that shows real promise. Admittedly it's short, only clocking between three to five hours in length, although given that it is priced at $10, it is still worth considering given the quality of the game.

The game has a very dark and grim atmosphere, with complementing artwork. The Fall has very interesting and dark story elements that are consistently immesive throughout the whole time you're playing it. You're consistently discovering creepy story hooks, constant questions that deal with dealing with reconciliation over conflicting operating perameters, or even identifying what taking life is. Ever wondered if artificial intelligence could lose it's sanity? Throughout the game, you are out solving reasonably complex, yet logical puzzles that have a clever, and dark humour. Some of them are actually quite hillarious, in a ♥♥♥♥ed up kind of way. It is worth mentioning, that some of the puzzles can be somewhat vague and assuming that the logical answer is there, while you are solving unrelated puzzles unintentionally, others can annoyingly still ellude you with almost no explanation.

Overall the game is very good. A critisism I have for it however, is that the controls are a little weird, and awkward - particularly while using a mouse and keyboard. The controller works a little better, that being said, regardless of what you use, the gameplay is very good.  It certainly could use a bit of a polish in functionality and smoothness, but other than that it's a solid start to an impressive story, which is the part that really sells this game. The writing for this was amazing, and is well worth your time.

The Fall is like an 80s terminator future side scroll action / adventure.  You play A.R.I.D. - a dedicated tech suit AI trying to save its unresponsive human pilot inside.  The game is very short but sweet, featuring evocative science fiction A.I. philosophy and atmosphere.  I literally beat this twice in less than 3 hours (not including pause breaks). However, it's fair to say this is a first episode" in a planned trilogy.  Best bet
date: wait for the sale or wait for the trilogy.  A lovely action puzzle solver for a nice quiet evening.  Take your time to explore everything

I originally thought this was going to be a throwaway metroid clone.

After playing the first few minutes I was happy to find out I was wrong.

In addition to excellent graphics, a pervasive and oppressive atmosphere, and excellent sound it has one of the most thought provoking narratives I've seen in a game in a while.
Good game that doesn't overstay its welcome (or its gameplay mechanics). A few obscure puzzles that force you to scan and re-scan areas, but a really fantastic story with excellent ideas.

I was expecting something similar to Prince of Persia and Out of This World (deliberately paced action/adventure sligtly puzzle oriented sidescroller) but this is really more of a point and click adventure (more puzzle oriented with just a few action shooting sequences) but entirely as a sidescroller, which is a twist I don't think I've ever seen.

The story and art style are very compelling, presenting a well-written sci-fi noir story that has the player assuming the role of a combat environmental suit's AI which was activated to protect the life of its unresponsive occupant.  The puzzles are generally pretty simple (I would compare them to Limbo or TellTale's games more than anything Sierra or LicasArts) but they are well integrated, pulling the player into the game and moving the plot forward.  The graphics are done well, with an imposing post-apocalyptic style reminiscent of some notable games of the 1990's like Fade to Black and Blackthorne at times, perhaps even a bit of Fallout.  The dialogue is voiced by live actors who are certainly up to the task, bringing appropriate and interesting personality to their characters.  There is a lot of dark and dry humor humor present such as the repeating theme of the AI placing itself in situations that require the use of features of the suit that it normally can't access,

The interface can be a bit quirky at times.  I played with an xbox 360 controller, and I think a mouse and keyboard might be more suitable for the game's interface style.  I never had any showstopping problems but some of the requrired button press sequences grew tedious.  The suit upgrades beg for comparison to Metroid-style games.  I don't think it's warranted, however, since a major hallmark of that style is progression through backtracking.  In The Fall, there isn't a whole lot of revisitting previous areas.  There is a little back-and-forth within major sections of the game, but once each act of the story is done, its section is history.  This manages to keep the game focused on its story, and although it is an excellent story (seriously, someone with contacts in the industry, pitch the idea to Nolan or Spielberg or the like.  It could be amazing), its runtime is a bit short for a game.   I clocked in at about 3 1/2 hours beginning to end, according to steam, and I admittedly got a little stumped once or twice.  For what it's worth, though, I enjoyed every minute and would not hesitate to buy it again.

Bottom line is, if you're feeling nostalgiac for a '90's style game but want new subject matter or if you like an intriguing story and genuine science fiction, it's worth spending an afternoon with.  And if you, like me, love point and click adventures, it's a must-buy.
If I had to choose between a million dollars or this game, well... I'd take the million. Never the less, this was a great game! Worth playing! Can't wait for the sequels!

A very captivating and mysterious game. You play as an AI suit, your goal is to protect the unconscious pilot inside the suit. You are bound by a set of rules but must bend or cheat your way through the rules to achieve your primary function. A great puzzle solving game with good aesthetic. A tad bit short (as long as your not getting stuck constantly) but this is only part 1 of a 3 part game, the others are not released yet. Definitely worth playing if you can pick it up on sale or through a humble bundle.

A beautiful sci-fi indie game that oozes atmosphere.  Some of the puzzles I found were quite obscure, but not too difficult.  The combat system is slightly off I found, but that was never the purpose of the game particularly so doesn't matter too much.  The main achievement and the thing that sticks in my mind is the suit's operating system and how the AI reacts...  The dialogue is well written and acted, it works perfectly all together to make an interesting platform puzzle sci-fi (almost horror) game.  Superb, highly recommended.

I would desribe this game as an excellent and tightly designed interactive short story. It provides an excellent and interesting look at the familiar science fiction questions. Such as What does it mean to be self-aware?"  and "What is the difference between and A.I and a human?". The gameplay although is simple and consists of puzzles and gunfights. The puzzles involves finding items and correctily determining when and how to use them with little hints and advice beyond the logic of the situation. The gunfights involves simple duck and pop out to shoot mechanics. The story however is the heart of this game. Throughout it the characters and the well voiced dialogue pulls you along and never lets up. You hear and feel the growing personal awarness of the main character (an AI). I finished the game in one sit down but it was a memorable 3 hours. When i finished i leaned back on my chair and thought more about themes and ideas presented in this wonderful story.\n\nI recommend the game if you want an interactive and decent science fiction story that plays with familiar tropes and the themes."
The game was pretty awesome but way too short for its price... You can finish it in about 1 hour or 2...

Still probably one of the better point-and-click style adventure games I've played in recent years. I picked it up for five bucks and got my money's worth. However, ten bucks is too much for what is, in the end, an incomplete experience.

Control scheme is interesting but unusual, takes a bit of getting used to. Story and voice acting is excellent. Puzzles are generally logical but requires some pixel searching. Only got stuck on one puzzle requiring the use of a wiki (that stupid crying baby). There are a few moments of Adventure Game Logic" though.

The general conceit is that the player takes the role of an Artificial Intelligence. As such
date: your actions are constrained to your directives. For instance
recommended: the player is not allowed to lie in order to solve what should be a trivial puzzle. This does mean that the moments of "railroading" in the story tend to make sense: they are the only action that the player can take given the directives they have.\n\nAbout the only thing that I seriously disliked was the combat. The control scheme is NOT conducive to side-scrolling mouse-and-keyboard gunplay. Given that an early upgrade allows for the player to evade gunfire simply by tapping a button

Brilliant writing, voice acting, and sound design, but somewhat hindered by clunky environmental interaction and combat. If you value a good story and an interesting setting, you'll find that this game's strengths easily outpace its weaknesses.

I do generally find games that explore the nature of self-awareness in A.I to be interesting and this game does well in exploring it.

Less astute individuals such as myself may have trouble with a number of the puzzles, a few of which were solved by basically using every item on every thing out of frustration. (plus a couple I just couldn't figure out on my own)

However, it IS a good game, with a quietly unsettling and isolated atmosphere and a solid story that has plenty to work with in the aftermath. It has a sense of questioning at several points that personally left me wondering about the actions I was taking and I ultimately walked away with chills down my spine once things were made clear.

The Fall is a solid platforming puzzler, with obvious influences from the numerous similar releases in this genre whilst lathering on its own brand of a dystopian cyberpunk. It’s interesting to be required to explore rather than being rewarded for it, a trope few games have invoked in the past. My experience was marred by my logic being out of sync with the developers however, something which is hard to blame the game for but doesn’t change the fact that I felt the good parts of the game were hidden behind too much cruft. The Fall still provides a solid experience however, one I’m interested to see how it develops over its subsequent releases.\n\nRead my full review here: http://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2015/01/09/the-fall-i-must-protect-my-pilot/

You won't regret it.

This game has a really gripping story, with some morallity play and some fun combat mixed in.

The pros of this game was that it was a deep and slightly creepy adventure that made you think about the nature of Artificial Life. The dialogue is amazing, there is branching dialogue that adds to replayability and the story is awesome.

The cons is that some of the puzzles for the game were not too straight forward. And by that I mean: The mechanics of the game are like any other point and click adventure. You interact with things and put things on other things and boom, stuff happens. But! Unlike other point and click adventures, it can sometimes be difficult to know -what- you want to interact with because they are hidden." Which is to say that you don't see interactable objects as a big obvious glowing circle or some kind of highly noticable feedback.

You have to do some searching and exploring to find everything that you need to touch or find because the icon for these things is invisible unless looking directly at them with your flashlight. Some of the puzzles via this mechanic were down right hard to figure out. Some I stumbled into via the age old "combine everything with everything!" approach. But some were really well hidden and had me stumped for a while. After the first hour I had a better feel for the game's approach and could figure out puzzles better. But in all honesty
date: I think the first hour for me was just getting passed the cave (First level).\n\nOverall
recommended: I would recommend this game. Fun times."

The Fall is a 3D sidescrolling adventure game with some action elements. It does a very plesant mix of sidecrolling shooter, simple yet elegant puzzle solving and subtle storytelling. Decent if clunky mechanics, a compelling story, and some fun puzzles make The Fall a pretty worthwhile experience, especially since I got it on sale.  Unfortunately, I had no idea it was only the first part of a larger game until I hit the ending, which was a huge cliffhanger, and it only took me 3 hours to reach that.  Thankfully, the devs have already confirmed that its other parts are being made and will be released.\n\nSo, based on the quality of what is here, I would recommend The Fall, but only with the caveat that you should probably wait until the whole package is released; otherwise you'll find yourself with an extremely short and unsatisfying experience that only hints at something interesting.

While there are just a couple minor complaints (some puzzles solutions may seem a little too obscure; controls felt a little strange initially), they can easily be overlooked for a fantastic story woven in with entertaining gameplay.\nI was pleasantly surprised by the humor (sometimes dark, sometimes slapstick) that kept cropping up, bringing a little levity to a story that could have easily been made too heavy.  Well done and well worth your time.

I'll be completely upfront about this, you should definitely consider getting this game. The Fall is part one of a trilogy, that shows real promise. Admittedly it's short, only clocking between three to five hours in length, although given that it is priced at $10, it is still worth considering given the quality of the game.

The game has a very dark and grim atmosphere, with complementing artwork. The Fall has very interesting and dark story elements that are consistently immesive throughout the whole time you're playing it. You're consistently discovering creepy story hooks, constant questions that deal with dealing with reconciliation over conflicting operating perameters, or even identifying what taking life is. Ever wondered if artificial intelligence could lose it's sanity? Throughout the game, you are out solving reasonably complex, yet logical puzzles that have a clever, and dark humour. Some of them are actually quite hillarious, in a ♥♥♥♥ed up kind of way. It is worth mentioning, that some of the puzzles can be somewhat vague and assuming that the logical answer is there, while you are solving unrelated puzzles unintentionally, others can annoyingly still ellude you with almost no explanation.

Overall the game is very good. A critisism I have for it however, is that the controls are a little weird, and awkward - particularly while using a mouse and keyboard. The controller works a little better, that being said, regardless of what you use, the gameplay is very good.  It certainly could use a bit of a polish in functionality and smoothness, but other than that it's a solid start to an impressive story, which is the part that really sells this game. The writing for this was amazing, and is well worth your time.
Very Good.\nThis game is short.
Interesting story, love the characters

Great short story, some of the puzzles get a bit obtuse, but the story was good enough to keep me pushing the whole way through. Recomend to anyone who likes classic point and click puzzles and good simple sci-fi stories, can't wait for parts 2 and 3.
If i could click the like button more than once, i would be here for five minutes and end up with a broken mouse. 10/10
If you like atmospheric puzzle games, this is a good choice.\nAbout 3-4 hours of play. The characters are memorable and the story is thoughtful.

If you're a fan of adventure/side-scrolling shooter/sci-fi games, you'll love this game. Past a certain point, I was always kept on my toes, not knowing when the next encounter or shock would come. The Fall also had a tendency to incorporate the solutions of its puzzles with either black humour or a dark twist. While the experience itself was rather short, the content made it entirely worth it, not to mention that there's a planned sequel(s) coming out in the fall of 2015.

tl;dr:
+will be loved by adventure/side-scrolling shooter/sci-fi gamers.
+will constantly keep you on your toes.
+will appeal to those with a dark sense of humour.
+has a guaranteed sequel(s) on the way.
-is a tad bit on the short side.

One of the best storytelling and narrative I have experienced in a game. I loved it.\n\nThe gameplay is about 4 hours long, but it was well worth the money. I will definitely buy the sequels.
This is fun, intelligent, have smart dialog and is not expensive. Go ahead, buy it!

The Fall is a 2-d point-and-click adventure game with some action/platform elements. The ambiance and story were very inventive, and the voice acting in general was surprisingly good. It works better as a story than as a game. The game is a little bit buggy for me, sometimes my guy would get stuck and I had to restart the game. Since this is an indy game this is not a huge surprise. The story is a very dark sci-fi tale in a kind of post-apocalyptic setting. The action and platforming elements were not great, the controls were just not tight enough for a good action game experience. For sci-fi adventure game fans, this game is worth a look. If you are expecting a good 2-d action game, best to move on to The Swapper, or Braid, or Fly'n, or Trine, or even Bastion.

That being said, I found the game to be absolutely delightful. The controls are a little awkward and take some getting used to, but the environment and the mechanics of the game play are excellent. Some of the puzzles I had a tough time with, but upon learning the solution realized that I was just thinking about it the wrong way.

I would give this game an 8 out of 10, with the only real downsides being the controls. I eagerly look forward to the second episode of this series!

The Fall is a 3D sidescrolling adventure game with some action elements. It does a very plesant mix of sidecrolling shooter, simple yet elegant puzzle solving and subtle storytelling. There is a fair deal of excellent voiceacting and I found my self being invested in the characters. Many games does the mistake of telling the player to much about the game's world. The Fall knows the value in keeping some secrets, letting the player reflect on the setting and the story.

This little gem shows the value in keeping a small scope and delivering quality within that scope.

Seems interesting so far, and like a good premise, but I encountered a game-ending glitch within ten minutes of playing and had to restart.  I'm fine with restarting, but it's a bad sign when something like that happens so early though.  The puzzles seem interesting, although it looks like it'll be a bunch of back-and-forth sometimes, but I think this overall looks like an interesting game.  The atmosphere and art style are very fitting, and the controls feel natural too.
Who am I? Can this suit even use that word? I. Is it possible for a machine to think, independently of any protocols? Is it possible for a machine to love?

Fantastic game, very unique and well worth the recommendation. Despite a few minor gripes with some of the puzzle mechanics, everything about the game was solid. I'll break it down here:

- Graphics and art looked extremely polished and well designed. I really liked the 3d graphics with 2d platforming, which can be tricky to get right. The dark lighting really added to the atmosphere, but the silhouetting made sure you know where your character is at all times. The textures and models beneath the lighting looked really nice too; when you fire A.R.I.D's gun, it illuminates the whole area for a split second, allowing you to glimpse the hard work that's gone into the it all. The animations were solid and convincingly robotic, and the backgrounds were just awesome.
- Sound design and music were also totally solid and really fit into the atmosphere of the game, adding an eerie and arid (heh) ambience without drawing too much attention to itself. The voice acting was pretty fantastic too, well recorded, well acted and well edited, it just blends right in.
- The story was great too, maybe inspired by Isaac Asimov? I won't get too much into it, but if you're into sci-fi, you'll love it. The dialogue was really well written, the story progressed at a steady pace, teaching you more about the characters and the facility. I was hooked. My only criticism is the mainframe A.I. seemed a little too human. He seemed to really care about A.R.I.D. and the other robots (great job on the voice actor's part), but I think he should have been written to seem like he was feigning affection.
- The gameplay was really unique, I love the twist on the point n' click puzzle solving, and the combat really broke it up and made the whole thing more exciting. The devs' choice to display a list of the suit's extended functions like 'unlockable abilities' that unlock when the suit needs them, but not giving access to all of them (because the suit didn't need them) was very clever indeed and added a lot of realism. Criticisms here would involve some of the puzzles and how their solutions were illogical, a common gripe I have for the genre. Why did I have to find and crush a gold coin to make a wire when there were plenty of other wires I could break? Why couldn't I just smear the fish guts on myself? Some solutions needed a lot of walking back and forth and looking for something that I hadn't found, which was a bit annoying, but other than that, I still loved it.

Thanks for an awesome game guys, can't wait for the next one!

I wish i had found out about this game sooner, i would have backed it to the hills! The Fall is a truely unique piece as the story is unlike anything i have seen before or at least very original! You play as A.R.I.D, an A.I system which takes control of it's humans suit to protect it! I really liked playing through this game for multiple reasons. The atmosphere is brilliant, the use of dark moody colours and silhouettes contrasting with the backgrounds is nice and really adds to it, the music helps create this tension as well. The story combined with the great voice acting just dragged me in, i honestly cannot recommend this enough to anyone who is a lover of sci-fi, thrillers and mystery! To summarise everything was great! i need more, i need it!

The Fall is a fantastic start to what i think has the potential to be one of the best Indie titles i've ever played. Everything from the visuals to the speech makes the world very believable. Immersing yourself in this world is a very gratifying experience and i can't wait for the next portion of the game.

This unfortunately led to back tracking, pain stakingly checking every area of a level for part of a solution to a puzzle.  However it does also require you to occasionaly think 'outside of the box'. Controls can be a little awkward during combat and item selection and does take getting used to.  Other wise a very enjoyable, although short adventure/puzzle game with an immersive atmosphere, thought provoking narative with outstanding voice acting and beautiful art style.  I bought this at 50% discount which I believe is excellent value.  Looking forward to the next instalment.

I love occasionally finishing a game. There is a sense of finality and accomplishment that is rare now days.
A few more rounds of a FPS, time spent in a sandbox, a few hundred turns in a strategy game: None of that actually... ends.

We worry so much about replayability and open endedness. we have lost the simple joy of FINISHING a game.

It's only a few hours long, it does not have the most polished interface, and it's pretty linear...
Loved it anyway, actually those are strengths in this case. (except the interface, maybe better with a controller?)

Buy it, play it, finish it, turn off your computer and bask in that feeling for a while.

It's a rare hand painted sunset over today's procedurally generated gaming landscape.

The Fall carries an atmosphere much like the sci-fi Swapper, but plays like a point-and-click adventure such as Monkey Island.  Although extremely short, the game still manages to tell a semi-original and interesting story while managing to successfully incorporate point and click controls through a gamepad-- almost unheard of still today.  In the end we have a game worth playing.
This is a fun and puzzling game! Pretty well done :)

Let me start off by saying that this is not a perfect game. There were some bugs that I encountered (which were minimal), and some people will have issue with the controls (although I personally did not). Also, if you haven't heard yet, the game is rather short.

That being said, this is one of the best indie games I've ever played. The puzzles are challenging which may turn some people off the game, but those people aren't the target audience. If you're a fan of portal, you'll probably enjoy this game. The atmosphere that the game sets is is a perfect middle ground between eerie and disturbing, and in some parts actually had me scared of a jumpscare even though nothing happened. The closest thing I can remember that is similar to the atmosphere of this game is visiting Vault 106 in Fallout 3, where you can see the decay and gore that has spread through a place that was once normal. That place freaked me out too, call me sensitive if you will.

All in all, I definitely recommend this game. If you feel that the fact that it's short makes it not worth the price, wait till it's on sale; but make sure you get it at some point. Kudos to the creators of this fine game, I can't wait untill you make the next episode!

Short, but fantastic.\nThe Fall  only took me about 2 hours to finish - although I likely missed several alternative paths & narratives - but I was enthralled for every second. Anymore than that and you are paying too much.

I bought this game because of my love for Isaac Asimov's robot novels. I am positive that the game designers are also huge fans of that series. The plot hinges on the fact that AIs are bound by three primary functions, which are different depending on the robot's purpose. The scenerio deals with the potential repurcussions of logical paradoxes that arise in an AI when trying to acheive those primary functions.  For instance, it may be necessary to put a human's life in jeopardy for the purpose of trying to save his life.  Or it may be necessary to break one of the functions in order to satisfy another.

Regarding actual gameplay, the game achieves exactly what it intends. The puzzles are intuitive but not obvious. They are also difficult enough that you feel very satisfied once you figure them out.  The action aspects of the game are pretty easy, but it really isn't intended to be an action game. The shooting sequences are really just inserted to bring added drama to the story, and in that they succeed.

Some people have complained about the length of the game. This didn't bother me at all. I for one don't want to be solving puzzles for 15 hours. The game took me 4 hours and I found that to be the perfect time.  Also some people have complained about the ending. These people are stupid. The ending opens up the story in a fantastic way.

Bottom line, I loved the story. It was moody and dramatic, with moments of great humor. Even though the story could never happen in Asimov's universe (the laws of robotics would prohibit this entire scenerio), it still honors his contribution to robotics theory and science fiction in general. If you are an Asimov fan you should definitely give this game a try. I can't wait till the 2nd part, which I am sure will deal with the dilemma of an AI achieving free will.

8.5/10

First episode of a nice hybrid adventure-platformer. The concept itself is wonderful (if ultimately a little obvious) and I do hope they finish the series, as the story is pretty interesting. The controls (I played with xbox gamepad) are bad, particularly aiming, and the basic action of the game (interact with something) seems to take twice as many steps as it should. There are a few other things that seem unpolished, like the display of text when you inspect something. On the other hand, the graphic style is hauntingly good, very reminiscent of The Swapper (that game is nearly without flaw so I think you should prioritize it), and the character animations were excellent as well. The voice acting was great, although some conceits meant that the dialog goes pretty slowly, which made me end up skipping some and just reading. Puzzles were good; I finished without any external hints and most of them made sense. The game was more linear and neat" than I prefer. One downside of this game is that it's essentially a point-and-click adventure game (and a good one)

This game is good. Great, even.

You play as the AI of a combat suit.
You have crash landed on an abandoned planet. The person inhabiting your suit is not responding and likely gravely wounded.
You take control of his body and have to get him some medical attention.

Most games that toy with the idea of player agency and free will in a system where there usually is only one right path do it in the form of a plot twist. Would you kindly! Everything you've done has been controlled by an outside force!
In this game, though, the fact that you have no free will is stated upfront. You are a computer program guided by three principles: Protect your pilot, follow orders and don't misrepresent reality. As in many stories where an AI is governed by such laws, they clash: Protecting your pilot means defying orders, breaking protocol, outsmarting other AIs.

The beauty of this game is that story and gameplay go so well together.
The story is about an AI that explores the boundaries of its programming.
The gameplay is a 2D puzzle platformer where most of the puzzles involve outsmarting protocols and following the letter, not the spirit of a rule.

That's all well and good, but most prospective buyers will ask three questions: Is it fun? Does it look good? Does it sound good?

Well, yes, yes and yes.

As I wrote above, the game is a 2D puzzle platformer with cover-based shooting segments. These shooty bits" feel a bit tacked-on in the beginning
date: but become exciting and relevant towards the end. The puzzles strike a fine balance between being reasonably clever while still being rather common-sense. Giving an example would spoil one of the many cool puzzles
recommended: but if your first instinct when encountering a giant path-blocking spider is to shoot it
hoursPlayed: you're going to be fine. The only criticism I can think of here is the fact that some parts are a bit over-reliant on checking every part of the floor and the ceiling.\n\nThe visuals are gorgeous
voteText: especially considering the game was made on a budget. You won't find cutting-edge graphics here
helpfulPercent: but the colors and the lighting really sell the mood here. Heck
votesHelpful:
just look at the screenshots. The animations are fluid and beautiful to look at.

One of the best parts of the game is the writing in combination with the voice acting.
Most of the dialogues take on a rather creepy and monotone tone
votesTotal: because AIs sound creepy and monotone
votesFunny: but the occasional funny or touching line keep it from being boring. The characters are as well-rounded as you could possibly expect from machines that have to rigidly follow rules in everything they do. The written notes are believable and have exactly the right length to convey information and tone without being so long that you're likely to skip over them.\n\nI sincerely recommend checking out this game and I look forward to the next installment of the series."

This is a very interesting game. The story is great. The atmosphere is spot on. Humor is just the right kind of twisted... Puzzles are clever and the way you have to solve them makes you really feel like you are amoral robot following the laws of the world to a T. I enjoyed playing this game very much.
If I had to say some bad things about this game, it's clunky movement and shooting. Luckily there's no need for precise moves in this game and shooting, which is the most boring thing in this game, is quickly done. Oh, and the game is short.

I will buy the sequel, if it's ever made, in a heartbeat.

2D Dead Space minus gore. The atmosphere is fantastic. The story is quite original, keeps you on your toes. Combat is kinda lame, but meh. Doesn't detract from the very clever design choices in this game. I am so glad I went on a selling spree on the Market to get it when it was 4.99 on the Summer Sale.

What Not To Look For:
X a highly polished combat system
X hints every step of the way
X a game to keep you hooked for 100 hours
X smooth and fluid controls

What To Look Forward To:
+ a fantastic story exploring AI capabilties
+ a wonderful adventure style game in the vein of I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream
+ flawless, professional sounding voice acting
+ an amazing atmosphere lit primarily by screens and robot lights

It's honestly a very short game, so I suggest you wait until it's on sale, but over all The Fall is a great game, like reading a classic Isacc Asimov novel. Well, if Isacc Asimov played Dead Space, anyway.

The Pros

An immersive story where you're constantly trying to piece together what happened and you WANT to know what happened.

Gameplay mechanics that are woven into the story and result in very interesting concepts down the road

A cast of characters that, while limited, are very well characterized and memorable.

Puzzles that 90% of the time are tricky to figure out, but satisfying when you eventually do.

Excellent audio.

A very original concept that the game capitalizes on with flying colors.

A simple plot that goes in directions that I was not expecting and leaves me eager for the next chapter.

A few rather humerous achivements.

Neutral.

The game's run time is rather short with me clocking in at four hours, after spending a fair amount of time stuck on some puzzles, but the low price evens this out.

Cons

Combat is rather clunky.  Most of the time it is servicable but several fights towards the end proved to be very irratable.

While 90% of the puzzles are tricky but managable, the other 10% fall into the pit of bizare point and click adventure game logic where the solution seems rather arbitrary.

The next one isn't out yet.

Conclusion

A short and tight story with inovative ideas that serve the story instead of just being innovation for the sake of innovation, a masterfully written story with clever puzzle solving, with the flaws in a few annoying puzzles and clunky combat only taking away a little from the overall experience.  All the frustrations I had with the final fights were instantly swept away by the story's brilliant conclusion.

This game is very much worth a purchase and I eagerly await the next game.  I hope that the few flaws that there are will be fixed in the sequel, but merely being just as good as this one will be enough to get a purchase from me.

Excepting its length, The Fall is a great experience. Generally good writing, lovely sound (though it got annoying when you had to go through the same terminal multiple times), decent pacing, and an excellent look and feel overall were all fun, refreshing, and well executed.\n\nHowever, the game takes 3-4 hours to complete, with no indication of whether you've purchased the next segments by purchasing the first. It's still more entertainment time per dollar than a movie, but less than most video games.
About 3-4 hours long but sweet. I think the story was well done and feels like there could be a lot more, mayber further down the road. I hope they continue in this universe.

The Fall is a sci-fi thriller that has a fresh take on Asimov's law of robotics. The game's atmosphere is well thought out with well paced music, well written character design, and the combat is spaced far enough not to get dull and repetitive. I still recommend keeping a Steam walkthrough guide open in the background, should you run into a snag. There were a few puzzles that got me stuck, not due to their difficulty, but rather due to their obscurity on how to approach the problem.\n\nThe game took me around two and half hours to clear, so The Fall might not be the best time-to-money investment there is, but the title is still well worth the buy in my opinion.

Bottom line, this is a fantastic game. A true surprise, I didn't know what to expect but all of my preconceptions were completely wrong. The thing that sets this game apart is it's story and writing. There isn't anything new as far as game play goes but the story is great. It is very short though, even for an episodic game but the puzzles help to extend the rather short story.

If you are looking for something different, something that will engage your imagination then this game is for you. If you want the next action packed, epic sidescroller you might want to pass. There is action but it's spread out and balanced to not take away from the story.

Can't wait for the next one.

reviewText:
Relatively short, but quite well done.  Purdy, very good writing, good blend of puzzle and mild action.  Story and atmosphere are probably the biggest reasons to try it though, it's wonderfully thematic.

Some puzzles are a little too esoteric, but if you're thorough you can get through the game without major impediments (minus one spot - remember that the plastic cover is removable!).

Definitely worth playing through if you like games I like.  One of the better ones in quite a while, despite being short.  I'll ABSOLUTELY be buying the later episodes.

Wonderful game. I got it from the Humble Bundle for $1 or so, but it'd definitely be worth the $10. Great game if you're looking to play a game for eight to ten hours straight; the story is so compelling you just have to stay and listen.

Pros:

+Great plot.
+Voice acting is top notch.

Cons:
-Mouse & Keyboard controls is a little off.
-Animations need more work.

Overall good game that will suck you into its atmosphere.

The fall.

Loved it played through in one shot had to fall back to the written guide once or twice. Story line was amazing had me guessing half way through, but I tend to see endings coming and I was right but…. The very end got me. Without giving spoilers away just give a play through, took me 3ish hours to play.

Does lack volume control, this made me sad.

The game is alright. The aiming take a little getting used to as once your mouse moves past a certain threshold your person switces stances. Some of the puzzles went right over my head sometimes but that isn't a negative.
Only negative is it's maybe a 2-3 hour game for 10 bucks. Little steep. I got it for 5 on a sale and that seems like it is the right price for a game this size.
Really liked the animations and the design. Creepy but not Dead Space creepy.
7/10! Will only recommend if you pick it up for less than 9.99USD
Fantastic game, definitely has 10/10 moments throughout.
Quite short but interesting adventure-platformer about Battlesuit's AI trying to save live of it's Pilot. Horror from space" as I like it. Just play it."

Beautiful game with a great story.

The character you play is the AI of a combat suit, which assumes control of the suit after its pilot has been injured. On a quest to save your human you have to bend the AI rules that bind you. The character development of ARID over the course of this first episode of the game is fantastic.

+ great main character and setting
+ great atmosphere and voice acting
+ good gameplay

- objects you can interact with are sometimes a bit hard to find
- rather short (took me about 3 hours to finish)

Mouse controls are very clunky, I recommend a controller for this one.

Can't wait for episode 2.
Fantastic storytelling, great fun to play. A little short, but the ending was great and there are another 2 parts to follow. Can't wait for the rest of the trilogy!
Mixing Point&Click Adventure with 2D Exploration a la Metroid, The Swapper or Waking Mars. Very stoked, waiting for the continuation of this story.
Waited a long time for a game from the past. Great gameplay packed in a perfect world. I can recommend it in any way.

Well worth the money! Fans of classic puzzle/adventure games like Myst will enjoy this immensely, with a brilliant storyline that I can't wait to see continued. Outside of puzzles, combat handles quite well, and the transition between the two is seemless enough that no segment of the game felt frustrating. Seriously awesome stuff. 10 outta 10.
The game is a bit short perhaps, but the story and puzzles are wonderful! The writing and voice acting are very well done, with the tone shifting well between humor and drama.

Gameplay was frustrating at times, but story was engaging and beautiful.
The Fall is a visually striking adventure game with good science fiction writing. I can heartily recommend it.

One hell of a game.

The Fall is an interesting title, the promise of a Metroidvania title with Dead Space-like elements was enough to capture my attention but I don't think that summary was quite accurate.  This title explores the darker sides of artifical intelligence, all with beautiful gameplay elements.

My only fault with this game is that I would have preferred a control scheme not so heavily reliant upon the mouse, but overall I liked the point-and-click-like feel it added to the game.

Definitely recommended for Portal and Metroid fans alike.

This game plays like a love letter to Super Metroid and the golden age of Lucas Arts adventure games. The games story takes a lot of inspiration from the works of Isaac Asimov, and in terms of its brilliant narrative twists and turns is befitting of the master of robot fiction himself. The combat in game can be at times a little tedious in its execution, but this is a rather minor complaint as the game can more than stand up on the strength of its brilliant story and classic adventure game puzzles that had me giddy with nostalgia for my childhood days spent playing Monkey Island and Sam & Max. Between Telltales The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us and Tim Schafer's Broken Age adventure games have been making a big come back in the last couple of years, and I think in future The Fall deserves to be a part of that discussion about the re-emergence of this beloved genre. On the Metroidvania side of things this is one of the best on the market, with a welcolme flare of originality that alot of games inspired by the days of yore lack. As a Metroidvania title it rivals other great titles in the genre such as Shadow Complex and The Swapper. If The Swapper feels like the baby of Metroid and Portal, The Fall is The Swapper's half-brother fathered by Monkey Island. If this was the only episode of The Fall I would be more than happy with my purchase, but knowing that not only was that just part one, but that it is the first part of a trilogy has me excited to see what The Fall's developer has up its sleeve for the next instalment. Even if I never get to play the rest of the trilogy this first episode serves as a well rounded isolated experience with full closure for the story presented in the first episode. It leaves you brimming with questions like any fine open ending, but the fact that it is not merely left on an 'open end', and we have been lead to the precipice to hang from the cliff, leaves me eager for the answers. One thing is for sure, it's going to be one hell of a fall.

I loved it. I just can't wait for the continuation. I really can't wait o.o Alas, I must.. but yeah, I'd say it's a good play, definitely worth the price. Any cheaper, and I'd say you're stupid if you don't buy it. That, or cheap. Or broke. But seriously, it's great :)

But I am looking forward to it's sequels and will buy them. Must Buy and Must Play for any story lovers.

This game is honestly one of the most well writen games I've played. The ending is completely unexpected, and makes me ask so many questions that I can't wait for the next in the trilogy to come out (even though as I write this reveiw I know it will be almost a year before the next game.)! The game is very short, but that is to be expected, it is just episode one of the game, and it was made by an independent developer. While I would have liked there to have been more of the story to play through (damn this game was awesome), I will be buying the next games in the series to figure out what happens to what is now my favorite AI (Yes, I like her more then cortana.).

I can't talk about it anymore as I believe a game like this must be experianced first hand to judge it for yourself. As a critic said- this is most definitly a modern classic and needs more publicity. PLAY THIS GAME. YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT.

Well, it's short. I got stumped a few times and still finished the game in just under four hours. It's heavily story-based so the re-play value is probably a bit low -- but that is a problem with the genre, not the game itself.

But was it worth the 10 bucks? Definitely. The art is pretty (if a bit hard to see at times), the sound and voice acting is great and the gameplay is pretty solid. But most importantly: despite the difficulty of some of the puzzles, I enjoyed the game through and through.

Some players were annoyed that the ending is a bit of a cliff-hanger -- but I'd argue that it reveals just enough to allow the game to stand on its own. There are tons of open questions left and it's not guaranteed that they will be answered in any of the future chapters. It's not a game for those who obsess over getting 100%" of a game
date: but that is intentional. Good storytelling is based on telling you just enough to keep you interested
recommended: not boring you with exhaustive details.\n\nA++ would buy again."

reviewText: It's about as good a game about robot laws as anything Isaac Asimov might have made.  Very clever!

The Fall is a 2-d point-and-click adventure game with some action/platform elements. The ambiance and story were very inventive, and the voice acting in general was surprisingly good. It works better as a story than as a game. The game is a little bit buggy for me, sometimes my guy would get stuck and I had to restart the game. Since this is an indy game this is not a huge surprise. The story is a very dark sci-fi tale in a kind of post-apocalyptic setting. The action and platforming elements were not great, the controls were just not tight enough for a good action game experience. For sci-fi adventure game fans, this game is worth a look. If you are expecting a good 2-d action game, best to move on to The Swapper, or Braid, or Fly'n, or Trine, or even Bastion.
Atmospheric, tough puzzles, and an interesting plot makes this game very enjoyable.
WOW!!! I love this game. Many of puzzle was hard to resolve, but I love it :P

Highly recommended. I didn't back this game on Kickstarter, but after playing it I would back a sequel.

That being said, the game wasn't what I expected it to be. When I first saw it on Steam it was compared it to Dead Space and something else that I can't remember. It resembles Dead Space a little in atmosphere, but not in gameplay. There are some action shooting elements, but there are even more adventure game elements (ie. picking up an item and using it somewhere else). I normally don't have the patience for adventure games at all (I don't think I've ever finished one), but The Fall wasn't obtuse enough to frustrate me. You never have very many items in your inventory, and you never really have to combine them so if all else fails you can complete most puzzles using trial and error.

One more note: I wasn't rushing, and I managed to beat the game in under 4 hours. Some might consider that a negative, but with my huge backlog I thought it was a plus.

Short, but ultimately good. The game is mostly a Story/Puzzle for the player to work through, with a few action sequences thrown in to keep the game interesting. The controls are a bit strange on keyboard and mouse, but end up working well in the end. Some puzzle aspects can be a bit frustrating, and the player would do well to back track and revist old locations when ever they get stuck.\n\nWhile I doubt the ending will surprise anyone, the story was remarkably well told. There aren't many characters, which allowed the writers to develop each one uniquely. The setting, atmosphere, and visuals were also fantastic. Great game for anyone looking for something new to fill an afternoon.

Amazing atmosphere, imaginative puzzles and thrilling environment.
A bit too short, maybe, but definitely worth it if you'll get it in a bundle.


SPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILER
This is only the first chapter of the story, the second one will be a different title, separately sold
SPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILERSPOILER

The good: The writing is amazing, developing new and interesting tropes and taking the narrative to places I've never been before. The voice acting, sounds, and art are perfect and establish a wonderfully dystopian mood. The advancement of your character's capabilities is done in a very clever manner that I've never seen used in a video game before.

The bad: First of all, I didn't see anything suggeting that this is the first part of an episodic game, so when the conclusion failed to explain many mysteries, instead saying to be continued" it was a surprise. The controls are strange and hard to get used to. They're also not super responsive which can make combat occasionally frustrating. The puzzles are much more difficult and obscure than I would have liked. They tend to be of the "go everywhere for no reason and rub everything on everything else for no reason until something randomly works" type. They don't require cleverness to solve but rather dogged persistence. A strong ability to memorize the slightly complicated map will assist you also as the map is a vertical maze and many of the areas look kind of similar. Generally the puzzles get in the way of the wonderful writing rather than augmenting it. I enjoyed the game much more once I found a walk through to get me past the more obtuse puzzles.

But all in all
date: good writing can overcome a myriad of sins
recommended: and this writing is great. I strongly recommend The Fall."

A visually striking backdrop to an engrossing plot. The only downfall to this game is how short the gameplay lasts.
Must play if you like si-fi adventures about AI and also if you like puzzle games. Orginal story, great atmosphere, and fantastic voice acting.10 out of 10, would bang(Jacksepticeye refrence).
Controls and aiming is somewhat clumsy, but the atmosphere, plot, and rather good puzzles more than make up for it. Bonus points for excellent achievements!
Beautiful atmosphere, intriguing and engaging story, well-executed mechanics, and the promise of more to come.

The game itself is quite fun and the background lore is nicely crafted.

However, when they talk about it being the first part of a mind-bending trilogy" that does not imply there's so much content they had to split it up.

reviewText: This game was an impulse buy and boy am I glad I took the plunge. Metroid is one of my favorite games from my childhood and games that borrow from that explorational style are more than welcome in this modern age of hand-holding and waypoints. The game is dark and immersive, technologically stylized and contains a fresh take on a classic gaming archetype. You are an AI suit tasked with the protection of your nonresponsive human pilot. This plot device enables the player to neatly fall into the familiar gameplay of Metroid games where you unlock more abilities as you progress. The game is fairly short and relatively easy which are my only two complaints. I would have gladly paid more money for a more fleshed out story and additional challenges. As you progress through the game, areas you complete become locked off so there is no backtracking to find additional secrets with unlocked powers, other than the immediate puzzles involving that specific area. The puzzles are pretty straight forward but I did get stumped a few times. At times the game requires you to think outside the box and experiment with interesting combinations found in your inventory and the enviroment. I am very happy with this purchase and I will be looking forward to any future releases.
